paule peter ſhould preach vnto v ſee experience actes xvij whē actes 17 paule preached audience dayly ſearched scripture whether ſayd haue bene long continuance cauſe blindnes groſſe errours ſecluded ſcriptures whiche cauſe ſuch groſſe errours ye fallen ſo ye could neither ſearch yet looke ala blindnes doth occupy eye ye ſo childiſh beleue ſame worde whiche hath made vnfaythfull heretickes faythfull chriſten tymes paſt nowe ſo farre altered ſhould cauſe faythfull chriſten become heretickes praye god open eye howbeit wee may nowe well taſt finger endes haue long bene miſerable caſe paule propheſied vppon v ij theſ ij2 theſſ 2 god hath ſent v ſtrong deluſions becauſe would receaue ye knowledge truth greater deluſion haue thinke woorde god whiche written comforte fode ſuſtenaunce ſoules whiche ſure metyarde perfect touchſtone iudgeth examineth thyngesrom 15 thinke ſaye wholeſome worde ſhould poyſon condemnation forefather haue lyued without receaued truth prelate belyes haue imagined yet theyr fault like although excuſe ignoraunce ſinne face god light god word opened vnto thē voluntary ignoraūce bee excuſednowe ſith haue light declared vnto v yet procede blynd ignorauncie conferre examine theſe iugglyng miſtes light god word ignoraunce wilfull without excuſe suffer therefore thynges ſoeuer tryed examined scripture true ſhall scripture doe hurt ſtabliſh ſtrēgthen scripture diſcloſeth nothyng falſehead cōdemneth nothyng damnable cauſe iohn frithes writyng againſt purgatoryand deſcend vnto matter diſputation whiche purgatory ſhall ſhew occaſiō take hand wrote letter vnto certaine frende england deſiryng hym inſtantly ſend certaine bookes though neceſſary vſe gotten theſe party chronicle syr thomas more booke agaynſt supplication beggers certein theſe bookes receaued vpon thomas day chriſtmaſſe yeare sauiour ccccc xxx letter written forme sir haue ſent ſuch bokes wrote one moe raſtels makyng wherin goeth proue purgatory naturall philoſophie whiche thyng quoth thinke eaſie thē proue good scripture c ſtuffe receaued meruelouſly deſirous tickled ſee reaſons brought probation begynnyng prologe booke ſet ſeuen reaſons ſayd fonde felowes alledged thē proue could purgatory deede fonde would deny purgatory better argumentes confute hee aſſigneth god grace propounde vij time ſeuen ſhal haue ſuch pith paineful purgatory ſhall bee able abyde worſt theſe ſeuē raſtell aſſigneth worth one beane read well pondered theſe reaſons thought hee ſhould ſharpely haue confuted thē might full well haue done ſpecially ſith owne imagination neuertheſſe came vnto ſolutions founde one certaine poyntes repugnaūt vnto scripture vnto reaſon muſt euer obediētmans reaſon muſt obedient scripture yea alſo extremely iniurious vnto chriſt precious bloud left read syr thomas more booke ſee scripture might bee brought purpoſe made diligēt enquire come lord rocheſters booke alſo writeth ſame matter well examined reaſons ſene order proceſſe scripture whiche alledgedaulus gelius founde clearely verified whiche aulus gellius ſayeth great deale better man bee ſharpely rebuked yea openly haue faultes publiſhed enemy bee coldly ſlenderly prayſed frendethe rebuke open enemy better ſclender prayſe frend man enemy enſearcheth narrowly gathereth together imagine ſo accuſeth man fumous heate veritie therfore audience wiſe conſider woordes therafter ſo geue ſmall credence el none vnto man frende audience doe prayſe hym ſlenderly coldly argument perſon faultie frende beholdeth quality circumſtaunces byrth bringyng vp feates hee hath done hys lyfe long yea applieth many thynges vnto frendes prayſe whiche ſerue ſinally leane nothing behynd may imagined employ frendes fame honour theſe pointes colour glorious apparant laud compelled lacke matter prayſe frēd ſlenderly audiēce wiſe may ſoone cōiecture prayſe worthy alſo may well doubt whether ſmall prayſe gaue true euē ſo read theſe bookes syr thomas lord rocheſter ſaw ſmall probation ſlender reaſons thoſe two witty learned men brought confirme purgatory conſidering alſo chiefeſt frendes proctours patrones therof applied many reaſons scripture purpoſe lacke matter rather made againſt yea onely alſo diſſented betwene ſelues probation ſayth water purgatory lord lord rocheſter agree rocheſter ſayth water maſter ſayth miniſters puniſhmēt deuils lord rocheſter ſayth miniſters puniſhment aungels maſter ſayth grace charitie lye paynes purgatory increaſed lord rocheſter ſaith ſoules purgatory obtain neither fayth grace charitie brought theſe thynges cōſidered made mine hart yerne fully cōſent paynefull purgatory vayne imagination hath long time deceaued people milked money notwithſtanding god hath left v two purgatory one purge purgatoryes god hath ordeyned hart clenſe filth whiche haue partly receaued adam nature child wrath ephe ij partly added thereto conſentyng vnto natural infirmitie purgatory word god chriſt ſayth iohn xv iohn 15 ye cleane worde whiche haue ſpoken vnto purgation purgatory hart obtayneth man thorough fayth vnfaythfull purged word god scribe phariſeis nothyng better hearing word rather worſſe teſtimony againſt vnto condemnatiō becauſe receaue purgatiō purgatory hart fayth onely beleuyng word therfore vertue purgyng applied alſo vnto fayth peter ſayth act xv gentile harte purged thorough fayth ſay beleuing word word verely preaching chriſtes death hath fully ſatiſfied ſinnes pacified euer father wrath towardes v c fayth purifieth hart geueth v gladnes ſoeuer moſt mercyfull father commaundeth v neuertheleſſe becauſe infirmitie purgatory member ſo great mēbers ſo weake fraile cā eſchew ſinne hart would wil deſireth therfore hath god left v purgatorye whiche chriſtes croſſe meane materiall croſſe ſelfe dyed ſpirituall croſſe aduerſitie tribulation worldly depreſſion c heb 12 called rodde ſcourge god wherewith ſcourgeth euery ſonne purgatory mēbers croſſe chriſt receaueth may remember law mortifie old adam fleſhly luſt el would waxe ſo rebellious would ſubdue v raigne v hold v thraull vnder ſinne ſoeuer haue committed crime thē god preſēt pſal 89 rod ſaith pſal lxxxix defile ceremony obſerue cōmaundementes rod ſhall puniſh ſinnes beatyngs ſhall reward iniquity yet mercy ſhall take neither deceaue hym promiſe croſſe muſt • eceaue god nayleth v croſſe heale infirmity glad hart thanke louing father medicine heale infirmitie ſubdue rebellion member member fully mortified death hath ſubdued corruptible body fleſh cōmitted reſt earth ceaſe purgatory god hath ordeined fully euill life papiſtes imagined purgatory ſelues purged ſight clergy could haue found harte haue taken theſe purgatory vppon neuer neded imagine ſith lyfe begā waxe ſo diſſolute ſpecially ſith ſhould ſalt earth lanternes light neceſſary imagine purgatory lyfe el might ſure moſt part neuer like come heauen iudge chriſten reader whiche haſt ſpirite diſcerne knoweſt voyce chriſte reaſons raſtell hath brought hath ſoluted mynde reaſōs ſolutions ſo childiſh vnſauery ſo vnlearned baren ſo full faultes phantaſies rather pitie man deepe ignoraunce blindneſſe hath ſo deceaued ſelfe philoſophie naturall reaſon thē feare vaine probation ſhould allure man conſent vnto hym iudge conferre scripture sir thomas lord rocheſter alledge theyr opinion doubt god ſhall open thine eye eſpy thing hath blinded iudge compare scripture together haue brought confirme purpoſe ponder reaſōs ſolutiōs vnto ſure thou ſhalt perceaue ſmall learnyng hath condemned theyr hyghe eloquence foly hath brought nought wiſedome youth hath diſcloſed old feſtred ignoraunce euen old practiſe wiſedome world fooliſhnes afore god god choſe foliſh thynges world confound wiſe choſe weake confounde mightye choſe vyle thynges whiche reputation confound high degree fleſh might boſt ſelfe ſight onely prayſe thankes euer amen ¶ prologe whereby man may better perceaue occaſion whole cauſe booke brother symon fiſhe maker booke supplication beggers named simon fiſhe whiche nowe truſt reſteth god handes whoſe eye god opened onely eſpy wily walkyng hipocrites ruyne realme whiche meanes nye hand alſo marke ponder peril mēs ſoules ignoraunt people ſeduction fallen franticke imagination feared pope hys decree whiche vanitie god ſelfe law whiche moſt righteous eternall man therfore feruent burnyng zeale hee bare wealth comminaltie brake touched theſe hypocrite litle treatiſe whiche hee called supplication beggers willyng rich beſtowed poore wee ſhoulde geue aboundaunce richeſſe vnto poore due law god ſhould lenger ſuffer ſelues bee diſpoyled robbed ſight ſturdy lubbars whiche vnder falſe cloke vertue prayer deceiue poore liuyng poore riche ſoules health credence geuen vnto theſe wilye fox either purgatory el pope mercyleſſe would haue pretēded cloke purgatory affirmyng due vnto becauſe praye frendes ſoules might come reſt aunſwered vnto poynt preuentyng theyr obiection proued either could ſuch purgatory el pope mercyleſſe tyraunt ſaith ſelfe may deliuer thēce except hee haue money point began whereat firſt began fume agaynſt ſuch denye purgatory fume tooke vpon hym ſelfe bee proctour purgatory ſay hyred ther ſpiritualtie although many men dare ſweare confirme purpoſe hee wreſted ſore scripture triumpheth alſo miſcreantes idolater beleue purgatory addeth thereto ſtabliſh matter man whiche beleueth god ſoule man immortall hee muſt nedes graunt purgatory tooke raſtell hold raſtell foloweth whiche printer dwellyng paules gate london maſter more alliaunce alſo coueteth counterfayte kinſmā although beames braines nothyng ſo radiaunt cō ueyaunce ſo commendable eye wiſe notwithſtandyng raſtell hath enterpriſed dilate matter hath diuided three dialoges imaginyng two men diſpute matter natural reaſon philoſophie ſecludyng chriſt scripture one ſhould diſpute name diſputers matter purgatory matter calleth gingemen fayneth hym turke mahometes law ſecond nameth comingo almany chriſtes fayth maketh turke teach chriſten mā ſhould beleue firſt dialoge goeth ſōme contentes raſtels iij dialogue proue reaſon god mercyfull righteous ſecond entendeth proue ſoule man immortall agaynſt theſe two dialogue diſpute partly becauſe treatiſe ſhould ouer long tedious partly becauſe thoſe twoo poyntes laboureth proue ſuch chriſten man deny although many probation ſo ſlender may well improued concerning thyrd dialogue wherin would proue purgatory wholly iniurious vnto bloude chriſte deſtruction chriſten fayth men ſo mad beleue vayne perſuaſions therfore thought expedient cōpare third dialoge deceitfull reaſons vnto true light pure worde god leaſt raſtell hym ſelfe might perceiue owne blind ignoraunce returne agayne right way man haue bene deceiued booke truſt except bee ignoraunt may repent hym glorifie god ineſtimable mercy hath ſent light world diſcloſe expell theyr darke blynd ignorauncy may ſee wayes walke prayſing lord eternally amen firſt booke whiche aunſwere vnto raſtelles dialogue man aunſwere raſtels dialogue thinke hath naturall wytte hee graunt booke raſtels making either true falſe falſe thē ſo euer ſéeme agrée naturall reaſon raſtels booke either true falſe allowed true muſt approue naturall reaſon muſt bee ruled scripture naturall reaſon conclude agaynſt scripture ſo falſe agréeyng scripture heard may conclude raſtels naturall reaſon conclude agaynſt scripture naturall reaſō falſe booke agréeyng scripture true allowed determine cōtrary scripture falſe bee abhorred ſoeuer ſéeme agrée naturall reaſon chriſten mā hee beleueth ſurely chriſt dyed ſinnes ſhould haue bene damned perpetually neuer haue entred ioyes heauen whiche thyng eaſie proued paule ſayth rom 5 thorough one mās ſinne adā enſued rom 5 death mē vnto condēnatiō euen ſo thorough one man righteouſnes chriſt came righteouſnes al men vnto ye iuſtification lyfe alſo iohn xi neceſſary iohn 11 one man dye people people periſhe ſo ben condemned periſhed perpetually chriſt dyed v raſtel turke gingemin excludeth chriſt knoweth death wherfore al yt reaſōs make vnto domeſday cā neuer proue purgatory except imagine y• muſt firſt go purgatory 2 raſtels boke clearely quickly confoūded hell playne cōcluſiō without chriſt exclude neuer come heauen fondnes inuent purgatory may ſée raſtels booke fully aunſwered lieth already dyrte thyrd dialogue falſe iniurious vnto bloud chriſt firſt ſecond dialogue although ſome errours agaynſt diuinitie good philoſophy yet wil paſſe ouer ſo blaſphemous agaynſt god chriſte thyrd notwithſtandyng thus leaue booke although might full well declare vnto ſolutions maketh theſe ſeuē weake reaſons hath propounded hym ſelfe hee auoydeth ſo ſlenderly man doubte purgatory would make hym ſweare booke none beſides hath one ſolutiō raſtel beaten wall certaine pointes repugnaūt vnto scripture ſo greate ſhame chriſten man ſhould printe much ſhame ſhould printed kynges priuilege firſt chiefeſt reaſon firſt chief reaſon made purgatory moueth man yea affirme purgatory whiche putteth firſt chapter third dialogue alſo y• laſt man ſayth made ſerue raſtell honour god man negligent commaundements god committe ſome veniall ſinne ought puniſhed iuſtice god dye ſodenly without repentaunce haue made ſufficiēt ſatiſfactiō vnto god worlde hys ſoule ought neither immediatly come glorious place heauen becauſe ſomewhat defouled ſinne neither ought go hell vnto eternal dānatiō al good order iuſtice ſoule muſt bee purged place make ſatiſfactiō thoſe offence may afterward • ee receiued glorious place heauē ſo iuſtice god muſt nedes purgatory forſoth reaſon hath ſome apperaunce aunſwere firſt argument truth ſimilitude wiſedome howbeit déede nothyng man imagination phantaſie compare vnto god word vaniſheth away regarde word lord therfore chaunceth euē ſame thyng vnto v happened vnto child iſraell pſal 81 people regarded pſal 81 voyce iſraell gaue bede vnto therfore let go appetite owne hart ſhall wander owne imagination goe inuention imaginatiō purgatory ponder iuſtice god balance mās iuſtice ſaying reaſon ſhould enter heauen haue ſatiſfied vnto god iniquitie except ſhould tormēted purified place ſurely euill takyng god man cōplection remitteth fault reſerueth payne nay nay chriſt gredy auenged thirſteth bloud ſuffered tormentes owne body deliuer v paine deſerued ſeyng thinke reaſō ſo ſtrōg inuincible confute one queſtion ſhal know whyther turne firſt ground vpon scripture paule writeth 1 theſſ 4 1 theſſ 4 maner liue remayning comming lord vnto iudgemēt ſhall come yere ſléepe lord himſelfe ſhall deſcende heauen ſhoute voyce archaungell trōpe god dead chriſt ſhall ariſe firſt ſhall whiche liue remaine bée caught vp alſo cloudes mete lorde ayre ſo ſhall euer lord harken queſtion queſtion thoſe men ſhalbe found alyue laſt day tyme noe euē ſo ſhall laſt day come vppon v vnwares théefe night math 24 math 24 thoſe men ſpeake ſhall thē ſaued mā confutatiō raſtels ſuttle imagination pure without ſpotte ſay except make ſatiſfaction ſelues vnto god muſt without ſpot wrincle ſhall enter heauē raſtell ſelfe doth proue ix chapter hys thyrd dialogue howbeit regarde teſtimony scripture affirmeth true paul ſayth epheſians epheſ 1 5 1 5 ſith muſt pure euē without ſpot wrincle ſhall enter heauen theſe perſons yet ſpotted ſinne haue neither place ſpace purge muſt néedes conclude whether muſt bee damned yet thinke vnreaſonable sée whyther argumentes naturall reaſon bring ſayth scripture verely paule 1 theſſ 4 eſpyed way ſaith ſo ſhall euer lord damned may euidently conclude ſome ſhal ſaued although ſinners neuer come purgatory taketh raſtell fall faultours raſtell ouerthrowē owne turne ſith god iuſt mercyfull ſhall ſhall go purgatory thē marke pray properly ſubſtauntiall reaſon wherewith go ſtabliſhe purgatory concludeth condemneth hell ſo many thouſandes yea euen paule affirmeth ſaued yet begynnyng ſéemed reaſonable haue proued ſufficiētly reaſon proue purgatory ſayd ſhall ſinners enter heauen neuer come purgatory peraduenture bee deſirous know god iuſtice pacified ſinne iuſtice god muſt néedes puniſhed world eſpy puniſhment therefore thought neceſſary imagine purgatory purge puniſh ſinne aunſwere paule chriſt ſonne god beyng 3 hebr 1 brightnes glory image ſubſtaūce bearing vp thing word power hath hys owne perſon purged ſinnes ſet right hande god chriſt onely purgatory purger ſins behold true purgatory conſumyng fire whiche hath fully burnt vp conſumed ſinnes hath euer pacified father wrath towardes v marke ſayth chriſt owne perſon hath purged ſinnes thou yet ſéeke purgation iniurious vnto bloud chriſt thou thought bloud ſufficiēt wouldeſt thou ſéeke purgatory geue thākes prayſe thy whole health ſaluation reioyſe whole lord paul writeth▪ epheſ 5 maner 4 ephe 5 chriſt loued congregation dyd ſent purgatory clenſed nay verely gaue hym ſelfe might ſāctifie clenſe fountaine water thorough word make vnto hym ſelfe glorious congregation without ſpot wrincle ſuch thyng ſhould bee holy without blame chriſt theſe meanes haue frutefull excellēt argument ſanctified made without ſpot wrincle blame agaynſt right caſt purgatory wherfore muſt néedes cōclude either paul ſaith true affirmeth chriſt hath ſo purged congregatiō el chriſt vnrighteous caſt purgatory whiche wtout ſpot wrincle blame ſight chriſt thoſe v hym 5 begynnyng worlde might bee holy without ſpotte ſight epheſ 1 choſyng ephe 1 election without ſpot ſight ala blind vnthāke chriſt election doth purge clenſe v fulnes ſuppoſe yet haue v tormented purgatory peraduenture euery man perceaueth meaneth 6 righteous hys ſight ſeyng euery man ſinner 1 iohn 1 therefore briefly declare 1 iohn 1 meanyng apoſtle firſt cleare caſe lyueth mā vppon earth without ſinne notwithſtandyng choſen chriſt foundatiō world laid without ſpot ſinne ſight god epheſ 1 ephe 1 ſinners righteous conſider imperfectiō fayth charitie conſider conflict fleſh ſpirite gala 5 conſider rebellious gallat 5 member ſold vnder ſinne rom 7 greuous rom 7 ſinners cōtrarywiſe beleue mercyable fauour god gaue moſt deare ſonne redeme v ſinne beleue imputeth ſinnes vnto v y• wrath pacified chriſt bloud beleue hée bath▪ fréely geuen v hys chriſt thinges ſo deſtitute gift rom viij rom 8 righteous ſight cō ſcience peace god thorough ſelues thorough lord ieſu chriſt rom v mayſt rom 5 thou perceaue thou art ſinner thy ſelfe yet art thou righteous chriſt thy ſinne imputed rekened vnto thée ſo god imputeth ſinnes bleſſed righteous without ſpot wrincle blame rom 4 pſal 31 therfore rom 4 pſal 31 neuer thruſt thē purgatory paule ſayth difference iuſtification freely doth exclude purgatory haue ſinned lacke y• glorye whiche god allowed iuſtified fréely grace y• redemption y• chriſt ieſu rom iij ſaye rom 3 ſhall yet go purgatory cal ye iuſtificatiō fréely grace lye paynes purgatory surely newe kynde ſpéech whiche thinke paule neuer vnderſtode peraduenture ſome man obiection thinke myne argumentes bee ſmall pyth diſſolue diſtinction ſaying truth yt god hath ſo purged clenſed v iniquity neuertheleſſe hys mercy purgyng forgeueneſſe haue onely purified v faulte crime payne due crime obiection aunſwere aunſwere firſt obiection god mercy thorough bloud ſonne ieſus haue remitted yt payne due vnto crime ſhall damned payne due vnto euery diſobedience agaynſt god eternall damnation therefore payne forgeuen v ſtill vnder cōdemnation ſo chriſtes bloud ſhed vayne could ſaue man ſay euerlaſtyng obiection payne wholy forgeuen v altered temporall payne purgatory pope may deliuer pardon el haue euaſ • may ſoone confute diuers reaſons firſt yt wordes nothyng 1 aunſwere ſecond obiection euen imagination cannot confirme ſayinges scripture neither ought accept thyng article fayth whiche approued god word may neither decline vnto right hand vnto left onely lord commaundeth v deut 4 5 12 13 agayne man ſhould aſke 2 authoritie pope geueth ſuch pardon aunſwere yt merites chriſtes paſſiō ſo laſt compelled pope • elleth chriſtes merites money graūt euen againſt ſelues chriſt hath onely deſerued v forgeuenes yt cryme alſo payne chriſt haue deſerued v geueth pope authoritie reſerue part deſeruynges ſell chriſtes merites money beſides euery chriſten man 3 ought apply vnto god thynges whiche ſhould employ honour farre forth scripture ſuffer ſeyng vnto honour god ſhould deliuer v bloud cryme payne alſo repugnaūt vnto scripture hath releſed v payne may robbe god honour well ſinne entent ſhould bee ſo vnkynde deſpoyle great honour without authoritie scripture imagine hath deliuered v payne well ſinne moreouer ſhould reſerue 4 blaſphemy ſay chriſtes bloud full remiſſion ſinnes payne full remiſſion forgeueneſſe blaſphemy thinke y• chriſtes bloud ſufficient geue full remiſſion vnto faythfull furthermore entent ſhould payne reſerued ſatiſfie 5 towardes god offence nay verely mē liuyng ſatiſfaction ſinne chriſtes death able ſatiſfie towardes god one ſinne neither paynes hell able purge one ſinne ſatiſfie length damned ſoules ſhould bee deliuered hell finally thinke 6 neuer temporall puniſhment inſtitute god ſatiſfactiō ſinne vſe tēporal paine chiefeſt cauſe ordeyned temporall paynes profitable 1 temporall paynes ordeined commō wealth may example learne vnfaithfull el feare god may leſt feare puniſhmēt abſteine committyng like offence theyr ſinne vnpuniſhed ſhould vice raigne vtter ſubuerſiō cōmon wealth alſo profitable 2 faythfull try purifie fayth god elect ſubdue mortifie carnall member may bee able ſerue brother withſtand vehemēt aſſaultes tēptation euer hand leſt ſhould waxe prowde boaſt ſelues thoſe giftes haue receiued god furthermore ſet aduaunce glory god put remembraunce made féele fraile nature ſo continually diſpleaſeth god father haue occaſion ponder compare trāſitory payne ſuffer thoſe enor mous treſpaſſes haue cōmitted worldly paynes ſufficiently puniſh ſinne ſo eſpy infinite mercy fauour god euen aduerſities compelled prayſe god mercyfull tender father whiche ſcourgeth v ſo fauorably thoſe greuous offence haue deſerued thouſande tymes puniſhment howbeit ſay truth man take ſuch profite men fayne puniſhed purgatory neither ſée heare neither haue mē tion made scripture may ſure ſo ſith scripture maketh mention purgatory haue infallible euidence onely phantaſticall imaginatiōs plaine inough ſuch thyng ordemed neither aduaunce god honour yet profit cominaltie el god elect ſure chriſt al apoſtles would haue forgottē haue remembred v let v ſée ſome raſtels reaſons ſayth fond felowes lay ſelues proue ſhould purgatory ſay ſayth raſtell contrition raſtels firſt argument ſome call repentaūce whiche payment ſatiſfaction ſinne ſay man committeth ſinne repentaunt therfore god goodneſſe doth forgeue repentaunce onely ſatiſfaction god woulde haue made done ſinne ſith mā ſuch repētaunce hath made ſuch payment ſatiſfaction ſinne god would haue made therefore man ſhould go purgatory haue new puniſhement death repētaunce ſhould voyde forſooth thinke neither raſtell frith euer heard ſuch reaſon neither yet man euer would fond argument ſo fonde ſay yt argumēt cōfuted purgatory except one y• cleane purged hys wytte whoſe reaſon ſo euer whether raſtels man let v lay vnto y• touchſtone scripture proue whether gold copper vpright counterfaite truth vntruth bee ſhort firſt propoſition maior reaſon cōtrition repentaūce payment ſatiſfaction ſinne ſtarke maior raſtels argument lye lye begyn withall contrition repentaūce ſacrifices woorkes adde helpe hym fully pay ſatiſfie ſinnes chriſt dead vayne mought full well haue ſpared bloud man deny ſet nought chriſt scripture marke procéedeth ſay ſaith raſtell raſtell man committeth ſinne repētaunt therfore god hys goodneſſe doth forgeue repentaunce onely ſatisfaction god would haue bee made done ſinne next part argument frith containeth two lye theined together ſayth whē man committeth ſinne repentaunt therefore god goodnes doth geue muſt firſt cōſider neither turke gingemin know thyng chriſt chriſtes death onely cauſe forg • • ene ſinnes chriſtes ſake repentaūce man imagine could mo • e goodnes god forgeue one ſinne iuſtice chriſtes death hath effect muſt nedes condemne ſecond lye repentaunce onely ſatiſfactiō god would haue made done ſinne true thē fayth falſe fayth holdeth • chriſte dyed v periſhed procéedeth raſtell though ſayd true maner raſtels fond argument beaten ground ſayth ſith man ſuch repentaunce hath made ſuch paymēt ſatiſfactiō ſinne god would haue made therfore man ſhould go purgatory haue new puniſhement death repentaunce ſhould bee voyde euen iuſt heauen fell ſhould catche larkes let v ſée properly • ée frith aunſwereth vnto owne queſtion ſhall finde moe blaſphemies agaynſt chriſt aunſwere preceded y• argument thinke man hath takē great paynes prepare ſelfe vnto matter three lye hee bryngeth thrée lye firſt chapter firſt ſayth onely ſoule ſuffereth body maketh comingo whō fayneth bee chriſten man folye naturall reaſon reaſon agaynſt scripture graunt well wiſely forſooth new learnyng déede true chriſtes body ſuffered harme neither ſcourged neither whē crowned thorne neither whē nayled croſſe report vnto owne ſelues ye cutte finger féele ye payne yet thinke ye ſay ye cutte ſoule hence forward ſée poore man ſhiueryng cold ſtréete may byd walke knaue beare hym hand féeleth harme man ſaith body féeleth harme promiſe honeſtie ſoule good concluſion catcheth cold néede make mo woordes matter ſith may make experiēce ſelues ſecond lye mā created god honour ſer • ice mā may ſay god honour conſi • teth ſeruice truth man made entent ſ • ruaūt ſeruice god hath néede ſeruice full honour well ſer • ed world begā honour ioye ſeruice whole hym ſelfe v neither employed diminiſhed cauſe hee made man man made man ſhould haue y• fruition ioy honour goodnes made v hée ſhould haue pleaſure v ſhould haue pleaſure hym third lye god made v pleaſure ſhould receaue pleaſure creature earth doth ſeruice honour god onely mā alſo ſtarke lye creature honour god creation whole glory creation redowneth honour god ſeruice cā better thē ſo gloriſie god neither • letteth bee idle woorketh thorough meruelous thynges glory fire commaūdement came downe frō heauen burnt sodome gomorra geneſis xix honour gene 19 exod 14 math 8 ſeruice made ſtronge burnyng wynde drye vp deuide red sea exod xiiij voyce winde ſea obedient wared calme math vi • j honour ſeruice man may ſée wytte ſo purged purgatory hee hath one droppe left eſpye truth yet let v ſée aunſwereth argument ſeuerally examine euery part firſt part raſtell contrition repentaunce payment ſatiſfaction ſinne hee aunſwereth raſtels fooliſh argumentes thou takeſt repētaunce aſ keſt mercy god thyne offēce mā ought ſo fooliſh thinke god ſhould bee reſtrayned cōpelled libertie whether forgeue would loth moue man frith aſke hym repentaunce ſurely farre gather wordes wotteth nothing meaneth pray ſée ſubſtantially aunſwereth argument argueth contrition repentaunce payment ſatiſfaction ſinne aū ſwereth neither yea nay feare trappyng beit wordes cleane agaynſt scripture aunſwereth thou takeſt repentaūce aſkeſt mercy god thy ſinne man ought ſo fooliſhe thinke god ſhould bée conſtrayned compelled forgeue thée y• ſure inough repentaunce payment ſatiſfaction ſinne repentaunce ſatiſfactiō ſinne chriſtes death onely argument falſly ſuppoſeth god iuſtice muſt néedes forgeue repent thē haue wholly payed may require right euen iuſtice thou obiect god reſtrayned compelled aunſwere nay rather greate pleaſure vnto forgeue mē ſo could make ſatiſfaction vnto hys iuſtice repentaunce reioyſeth puniſhyng v addeth raſtell raſtell libertie alway execute iuſtice mercy pleaſure aūſwere hath pleaſure agaynſt scripture frith therein hath fully opened pleaſure pleaſure forgeue god forgeueth chriſtes • ake otherwiſe fréely beleue ſonne chriſt ieſu condemne thē beleue raſtell meane faſhion graunt hym vnderſtād god taketh hys pleaſure libertie miniſtryng mercy iuſtice ſo hee may condemne hath geuen payment full ſatiſfaction ſinne ſéemeth • e ſhould meane ſeing hee denyeth firſt part argument agayne ſaue hym beleued ſay raſtell rūneth ryotte taketh hys raſtell groundeth hym vppon lye imagination pleaſure god hath power agaynſt hym ſelfe hys scripture looke hath promiſed performe therfore raſtell proue purgatory hée groundeth hym ſo many lye yet neceſſary declare vnto ſatiſfaction ſinne ſhall ſée whether purgatory may ſtand paule ſayth hebr x chriſt 8 heb 10 one oblation hath ſatiſfied ſinnes halowed ſaith hee offeryng body chriſt ieſu whiche done vppon croſſe one oblation hath hee made whiche halowed perfite euer true made perfite oblation hys owne body vppon croſſe purgatory chriſtes merites vtterly ſetteth aſide purgatory vayne haue ſo purged v néede purgation made perfite thorough hym néede lyfe bee purged • hee haue ſatiſfied v ſéeke ſatiſfaction leaue fountaine liuing water ſéeke refreſhing polluted pooles ſpecially ſith headſpryng ſo ready hand muſt make ſatiſfaction vnto god ſinnes would 9 know chriſt died thinke ye meane purge v onely death chriſt bloud ſhed vayne doubt way vnto father thē chriſtes bloud whether purgatory ſacrifices thou canſt imagine thē death neceſſary ala vnkindneſſe y• ſo deiect precious bloud chriſt ſet gracious fauour naught meanes may ſatiſfie ſinnes néede redemer yet • auour may call right duety ſo néede chriſtes bloud mercy fauor may blaſphemous vnto chriſtes bloud frée redemption chriſt able fully euer 10 ſaue thē come vnto god hym ſeyng hee euer lyueth make interceſſion chriſt hable fully ſaue commeth god v hebr v • j able fully euer ſaue v runne hym ſéeke purgatory make interceſſion v lyke cruell ſtepfather towardes v rather y• meanes hee ſéeketh health flye hym offereth hym ſelfe ſo louyngly v dar • put truſt hym whiche enemyes vouchſafed dye v reconcile v vnto father rom 5 maketh comyngo almany rom 5 bryng example confutyng thinketh wynne fielde ſhew ſimilitude nothing lyke dede imagine lyke doth cōfute maketh ſtronger example owe thee c li true debt humbly deſire thee forgeue diſcharge raſtell pardon thou make cleare releaſe therof bounde make thee payment ſatiſfaction proue ſimilitude nought frith nothyng lyke purpoſe eaſ • e purpoſe firſt part argument contrition repētaunce paymēt ſatiſfactiō ſinne therfore haue like raſtels ſimilitude good muſt ſuppoſe humble requeſt forgeueneſſe diſcharge pardon payment ſatiſfaction c li therfore vpō ſhould firſt haue agréed el cā example ſerue nothyng make lyke imagine humble deſire forgeuenes payment ſatiſfactiō c li hath made rod arſe ſhall neuer able auoyde let v ſée aunſwere caſe haue put raſtell ſayth raſtell deſire forgeueneſſe c li yet libertie gentlenes whether forgeue thee whole c li el part therof well hitte maſter iohn ſhould pay c li frith good curraunt money yet libertie gentleneſſe whether would forgeue part whole therof truly would loth one debtours • e ſo hard creditours like maior haue ſtudyed ſome cautell law neuer heard owed c li gaue payment ſatiſfaction therof ſhould bee cleane diſcharged whether ye would yea nay neither néede thanke liberalitie gentlenes caſe requeſt minor deſire forgeuenes muſt payment ſatiſfactiō y• c li el nothyng lyke argument ſo may put ſimilitude purſe til place tyme ſhal better agrée wherfore muſt néedes cō clude deſire forgeuenes cōcluſio ſtanding ſayd deſire forgeuenes raſtels ſimilitude clearely cō founded payment ſatiſfaction c li el ſayd nothyng lyke cleane diſcharged néede neither thanke liberalitie gentleneſſe obiect recompenſe loſſe tyme damage hurt hinderaunce haue none paymēt c li ſo forth applyed vnto god remiſſion ſinnes ſuch loſſe doynges •… god neither better worſe tyme damage hurt hinderaūce towardes god neither hurt hynder hym although neuer aſke forgeueneſſe damned perpetually profite aſke hurt hinderaūce • aſke owe mā xx li l •• ger kéepe profi • e loſſe god receaueth v • young receaueth v mās ſtate receaueth v old thinketh loſſe hurt receaue v ſaith prophet wickednes wicked ſhal 11 hurt hym day ſoeuer hée turne vngodlyneſſe • zech ezech 33 xxxi • j ſhould ſurely hurt hym hee ſhould broyle purgatory wherfore either ſuch paynefull purgatory el ſée prophet whiche ſpeaketh theſe woordes perſon god ſhould true ſhall poure vpon cleane water 12 ezech 36 chriſt haue purged v cleane w •… deth purgatory 13 ſayth god father ſhalbee clenſed iniquity ezech xxxvi bee purged néede purgatory néede purgyng clenſed ſurely conuerte iuda turne iſraell vnto purifie theyr iniquity wherewith hau • offended hieremie xxxi • j hée purifie • erem 33 ſhould purgatory mercyfull vnto wickednes 14 ſinnes remember hieremy xxxj hebr vi • j ierem 32 hee remember ſinnes may ſure frye v fire purgatory ſinnes let v ſée ſecōd argumēt ſecond argument iiij chap ſurely fond beit ſolution yet fooliſhe ſumme argument man made ordeined raſtell haue infinite beyng therfore mortalitie death hee muſt haue infinite ioye infinite payne put like argument frith man ordeined world kyng ſubiect therefore borne euer kyng el euer ſubiect may falſe raſtels ſecond argument confuted peraduenture may borne ſubiect made king el may bee borne kyng depoſed made ſubiect therefore argument holdeth formally holdeth maner ſhould ſay ape thou muſt néedes ape aſſe whiche true ſhould ſay ſame wordes iohn raſtell thinke would anyppyng concluſion angry ſay falſe ſuppoſe ſcholemen ſay lyeth put hym example infantes dye without chriſtendome whiche ſcholemen ſay ſhall neuer haue ioy payne wil graunt argument ſée properly confute marke aunſwere ſtandeth v chapter degree ſinnes ſome raſtell ſinnes great ſome greater therfore muſt degree puniſhment ſome puniſhment great ſome greater well pleaſure content graūt frith el matter worthy diſputation man ſayth raſtell earth hath committed raſtell great ſinne offence taken repentaunce whereby ſinne forgeuē marke beyng ignoraunt chriſt ſayth repentaunce ſinne forgeuē yet raſtelles fond argument proue purgatory hath taken ſuch ſufficient repē taunce therfore ſufficiēt puniſhmēt ſhould make full payment ſatiſfaction ſinne dyeth condigne full ſatiſfaction made god muſt righteouſnes ordeine place purgatory wher ſoule ſhall haue puniſhment make condigne full ſatiſfaction ſinne ſo bee purged purified ſhalbe able woorthy admitted receaue eternall ioye heauen firſt brother muſt graunt frith haue chriſt chriſt redemer redemer iuſtifier iuſtifier none ſuch raſtels ſecond argument clearly cōfuted raſtell turke gingemini ſuppoſe repentaunce worlde could ſatiſfie one ſinne ſoeuer committed ſinne ſhould damned therfore raſtell ſpeaketh ſeyeth diminutiues ſhould truth ſpye hell eſpyeth purgatory ſhould ſay ſinners ſticke chriſtes bloud ſhall damned eternally ſayth ſhalbe puniſhed purgatory ſhort raſtell ſay truth thē chriſt dead vayne hee ſay truth ſticke reaſō peraduenture aunſwere obiection thou knoweſt chriſt wilt ſay many doe chriſtes death redemptiō ſerueth thée original ſinne moſt thoſe ſinnes thou committedeſt baptiſme aunſwere iohn child write vnto 15 ye ſinne man ſinne yet haue aduocate father ieſus chriſte whiche righteous obtaineth grace ſins ſinnes onely alſo ſinnes world whō wrote iohn 1 iohn 2 epiſtle thinke wrote vnto chriſten ready baptiſed yet ſayd man ſinne haue aduocate ye father ieſus chriſt righteous obtaineth grace ſinnes loe adnumbreth ſelfe alſo ſayth haue aduocate ſaith agayn ſinnes ye may ſée meaneth onely original ſinne neither yet ſinnes done baptiſme doubt baptized whē wrote epiſtle yet ſayd ſinne meaning fall ſinne haue remedy chriſt aduocate baptiſme ſoeuer haue aduocate father ieſus chriſt iohns learning knew remedy fell ſinne onely chriſt notwithſtandyng prelate haue practiſed ſay man ſinne ſhal lye paynes purgatory vntill deliuered thence maſſe penny pope pardon certaine suffragies without money may ſure chriſt ſayth man commeth vnto 16 father thorough iohn iohn 13 xiij ſayth hee way yes lord prelate haue eſpyed way whiche although paynfull vnto poore yet profitable prelate come vnto ye labour 17 laden eaſe ſayth sauiour chriſt ieſu math xj math 11 wilt thou ſend v lord purgatory forſooth litle eaſe purgatory • icke purſe fire bee ſo hote prelate haue fayned euen put thine iniquity 18 eſay 43 mine ſake ſayth god father thy ſinnes remember eſay xliij ergo broylyng purgatory putteth away ſinne hee putteth away broylyng purgatory addeth alſo hee remember ſinnes call ye remembraunce caſt v purgatory god predeſtinated 19 called hée called iuſtified dyd thē thoſe god calleth iuſtifieth 〈◊〉 glorifieth dyd caſt purgatory clēſed forſooth apoſtle maketh mentiō therof addeth immediatly iuſtified glorified rom viij wherfore let rom 8 v put ſuch obſtacles vnkynde vnto gracious fauour god beſides paule forbidedth v 20 carefull ſlepe ſay yt dead haue hope ſurely knowne 1 theſſ 4▪ purgatory hee would haue bene carefull ſith fayne ſuch miſerable tormentes ſeyng occaſion make mention dead ſpake one word purgatory playne inough knew nothyng el hee negligent ouerhyppe yet leuer ſay purgatory phanſie man imagination purgatory phantaſie man imagination aſcribe ſuch forgetfulnes negligence vnto apoſtle thyrd reaſon raſtell allegeth thyrde argument vj chapter ſūme degree ioye heauen degree payne hell therefore may god paſſe euery mā geue accordyng deſerte either leſſe neuer neede purgatory well let v graūt theſe degrées raſtels pleaſure although queſtion ſ • diſputable ſure defend foloweth ſooth bryngeth proper example could ſerue ye purpoſe let v paſſe ouer ſolutiō end vij chapter whē man ſayth raſtell infected raſtell ſolution raſtels thyrd argument great mortall ſinne ſo depart ſoule ought doe ſeruice heauen vnto god becauſe putrified foule ſinne man taken medicine full repentaunce hys lyfe medicine would haue reſtored againe ſoule health vertue frith muſt remember chriſt dead vayne repentaunce medicine reſtoreth agayne health vertue ſoule néedeth chriſt forth raſtell haue taken ſayth raſtell ſome repē taunce ſinne ſufficient ſufficient tyme make ſufficient ſatiſfaction therfore yet takyng medicine repentaunce ſinne expelled gone ſoule ſickeneſſe ſinne clearely whole yet ſpottes token ſinne deformitie ſoule doe ſtill remayne till ſoule haue time purged thoſe token ſpottes make pure cleane deformitie man euer one ſuppoſition frith falſe iniurious vnto precious bloud chriſt wonder taught concluſion hee graunteth ſo ſoone vnto would haue graunted god neither y• ſoule immortall although true vntil proued thought ſelf good naturall reaſon raſtels naturall reaſō doth fouly deceaue hym turke ginge •… ſtarke falſe ſay repentaūce excludeth chriſt doth ſatiſfie ſinne hee neuer putteth queſtion graunteth belike turkes haue ſuch opinion let go turke let v chriſten men graunt nothing contrary ſcripture euer captiuate reaſon vnto infallible reaſō wiſedome god paſſeth reaſon farre fourth reaſon propounded iiij argument viij chapter whiche ſoule vnpurged maye doe ſome meane low ſeruice god epheſ 5 heauen though bee higheſt beſt thing falſe agaynſt scripture epheſ v cāt iiij let v ſée aunſwere maketh cant 4 vnto aūſwere begynneth raſtell ix chap ſumme heauen ſo pure cleane raſtelles aunſwere iiij argument nature muſt expell maner impuritie vnclennes neither ſuffer thyng therin maner vnclenneſſe euill thyng vnpleaſaunt foloweth mā hath cōmitted mortall ſinne taketh repentaunce whiche healed foule infirmitie sée harpeth one ſtring whiche alſo ſo farre tune wonder man cā abyde heale mine raſtell infirmitie repentaūce wherfore dyed chriſt yet ſayth frith ſpots token remayne lacke ful ſatiſfaction aunſwere remaineth euery whitte ſinne ſpottes token together except chriſt haue takē frō v death bitter paſſiō therfore ſaith raſtel god iuſtice may raſtell condemne ſoule eternall paine hell offence purged put away wherwith purged put away remiſſion ſinne 21 frith hebr 9 without bloud hebr ix remiſſiō without bloud ſhall repentaunce doe bloud sinne takē away yt bloud ieſu chriſt chriſt excluded yea ſhall thy purgatory doe bloudſhed nothyng taketh awaye ſinne onely bloud chriſt ieſu ſhed redemption yet ſayth raſtell god raſtell iuſtice hys diſcrete wyſedome goodnes ought immediatly receaue ſoule cleane moſt pure place heauen accompany pure aungels c mary waraunt frith mery cō cluſion iohn frith thée afrayde neither gyngemin thy companyon thou neither ſhall enter either immediatly mediatlye ye exclude chriſt ye haue done hetherto ye taken repentaūce world would thereto imagine many purgatoryes peſen monkes coule chriſt lambe god 22 taketh awaye ſinne world iohn hath purged iohn 1 ſinne ſitteth right hand father hebr heb 1 hath purged ſinne hath made v hys ſight yt ſight father without ſpot wrincle epheſ beit ſight ephe 1 finde ſelues ſinners iohn 1 iohn 1 maketh v bleſſed righteous imputeth ſinnes vnto rom 4 nede purgatory v rom iiij néedeth purgatory fift argumēt bryngeth v argument raſtell agaynſt purgatory touched x chapter ſumme ſhould ſeeme conuenient purgatory one ſhuld earth partly becauſe body offendeth ſoule might purged ſoule partly bee good example men lyuing put feare doe like offence ſo ſhould cauſe many abſtayne committyng ſuch lyke offence ſinne elles ſhould purgatory reaſon hath great pyth frith notwithſtanding well proſecuted would hard raſtell auoyde formall raſtel proueth purgatory vpon earth argument méete yt body offendeth ſoule ſhould purged ſoule ergo purgatory muſt vppon earth god may ioyne body ſoule together agayne departed ſo puniſhe together although purgatory earth euen ſoeuer therfore thus thinketh ſhoulde well followe body felow partener 23 ſoule committyng crime ſinne ſhall alſo partaker glory prepared loue god wherfore reaſon ſoule ſhould bee purged puniſhed purgatory body ſhould alſo ſuffer hym purgatory fayne place purgatory heauen earth hell wote ye raſtelles fond concluſiō v argument raſtell would ſay vnto forſooth euen dyd firſt chapter thyrd dialogue ſay hee would ſtoutely affirme body ſuffereth neither well woe ioy payne good euill therfore needeth goe purgatory reaſon follie body ſhould go either heauen hell neither féeleth pleaſure payne new learnyng déede thinke chriſten man ſo fooliſhe beleue hym ſecond poynt ſhould good example put men feare committyng ſuch treſpaſſes ſoone aunſwered may abſteine ſinne feare loue ought abſtaine eui • l becauſe yt puniſhmēt foloweth crime onely loue haue god without reſpect either ſaluation damnatiō thou abſtaine feare ſo art thou vnder law vnder damnatiō law god law man farre vnlike law mā fulfilled exteriour act although hart farre owe law god law man doth greatly vary man xx pound compelled law pay hym certaine day pay albeit myne hart neuer ſo grudging euill willing yet haue fulfilled law ſo ſhall proceſſe ſentence paſſe agaynſt god law requireth thyng bee done well willyng hart euē pure loue thou feare vnwillyngly yt ſhall imputed vnto thée ſinne thou feare workeſt thou loue rather hateſt thing thou doeſt alſo law conſtraineth vnto thou vnwillyngly law god requireth hart mynde willeſt thou contrary ſo wouldeſt thou ſuch lawe neither yet god ſhould iudge thée ſo doyng ſith god iudgeth thée thine hart law man requireth body outwarde deedes muſt hée néedes condemne thée thou willeſt contrary vnto law wil yea willeſt thine hart contrary thou doeſt thyne outward déede let v ſée ſolution xi chapter ſo fooliſh great length chapter loſſe tyme coſt printyng would ſurely haue aunſwered vnto length euen ſhould haue ben aſhamed hym ſelfe ſhort raſtels fooliſh ſolutiō fifth argument touch ſome hys woordes firſt part argument entendeth aunſwere ſhould ſeeme cōuenient purgatory ſhould earth becauſe body offendeth ſoule ſhould bee purged ſoule reaſon value haue ſhewed ſayth raſtell reaſon ſayth raſtellraſtelles ſolution proueth onely purgatory alſo ſhould neither heauen hell man haue lyued ſo vertuouſlye earth ought ſaued goe ioyes heauen let v pardon hym lye prophet ſayth man ſhall iuſtified ye ſight god enter iudgement v pſalme c xliijpſal 143 yet neuer meritorious acte onely ſoule ioyned body ſhould neuer rewarded earth ſoule ioyned body raſtels reaſon fayleth hym may ye perceaue frith raſtell thinketh heauen hell euen thus body ſhall neuer come heauen hell whiche poynte touche largely none firſt comingo hys argument ſayth ſhould ſéeme conuenient purgatory vpō earth ſayth raſtell yt would take away libertie prerogatiue authoritie god example would ſay ſhould ſéeme cō uenient byſhop london palace ſhould londō partly becauſe ye chiefeſt citie dioceſſe raſtell doth much abuſe ſelfe partly becauſe nigh court whereto may better reſort get promotion would raſtell ſay tooke byſhops libertie prerogatiue authoritie might ſet would belike mā hath dronke mery cuppe affirmeth alſo argument taketh raſtell frith away heauen hell ſo becauſe hee ſuppoſeth conuenient purgatory ſhould vppon earth albeit ſay conuenient yet ſayth hee muſt needes nay thyng raſtels ſore yes abyde verelye added moſt conuenient body whiche partaker committyng crime ſhould alſo purged puniſhed ſoule ye knowe plucketh raſtell beard went proue raſtell contrary hym ſelfe contrary firſt chapter ye body hath neither payne pleaſure c ſhould take away heauen hell ſooth maner raſtell thinketh god cā ioyne body agayne ſoule tranſitory life may together receaue ioye payne yt paſſeth natural philoſophy thus imagineth body ſoule departed thē ſay adieu euer day therfore thinketh god puniſh hell together ſaue together heauen thē muſt take while liuyng earth ſo raſtell hath foule ouerthrow ſuppoſition body muſt ſuffer ye ſoule raſtels learnyng muſt proue heauen hell earth el cā none sée learned man yt would proue purgatory good philoſophy ſecond cauſe purgatory ſhould good example liuing put feare like offence ſoluted raſtell haue ſoluted yet ſatiſfie agayne becauſe raſtell leaueth outraſtels ſolution confuted haue ye world moſes prophetes ye old teſtament yea alſo chriſt apoſtles call new teſtament beleue theſe thē ſhall ſurely beleue although purgatory hel amōg v may well bee gathered chriſtes owne wordes luke xvj luke 16 brought ye parable ye rich mā lazarus ye rich mā paynes deſired abrahā ſend lazarus vnto v brethrē warne might come fire abrahā aunſwered agayne yt moſes prophetes added let heare thē ſayd rich mā nay father abrahā departed appeare vnto beleue abraham concludeth maner beleue moſes prophetes wil beleue dead ſhould riſe agayne therfore may likewiſe conclude beleue nota true good concluſion neither yet feare paynes moſes prophet yea chriſt apoſtles haue propheſied fall vnfaythfull beleue feare paynes purgatory raſtellnow laſt pointe purgatory ſhould aunſwereth ſhall heare frithfirſt yt fooliſh queſtion hee aunſwere vnto philoſophy raſtell tell purgatory whether earth el whereand ſayth man tell neither place neither yet maner payne maketh thomas yea scholemen fooles craft partly becauſe take vpon aunſwere vnto queſtion whiche calleth fooliſh partly becauſe fully determine place purgatory third place hell aſſigne fire maner yt payne raſtell proueth ſcholemen double foolesand agayne laſt part hee proueth thē double fooles becauſe ſtoutly affirme thyng man tell raſtel ſayth agayne becauſe reſtrayne god libertie aſſigne place make ofleſſe authoritie inferiour iudge hath place aſſigned hym may doe execution puniſh giltie place wonder scholemen may abyde felow raſtelland ſayth purgatory place limitatiue ſoeuer god doth limitte ſoule bee purged limitatiue place ſoule purgatory ſoule purgatory one place onely many diuers platesso yt man may gather raſtell ſoules bee limited one place purged puniſhed therto agréeth alſo ſimilitude iudge whiche aſſigneth one puniſhed one place place euen pleaſure ſuch geare come beyond sea ſhould ſoone haue bene condemned although bene halfe ſo greuous agaynſt scholemen let paſſe well worthy let v ſée examine newfangled philoſophy come vnto ſixte raſtels vi argument argument whiche begynneth xij chapter effect repentaunce full payment ſatiſfaction ſinne bryngeth remiſsion therfore ſoone repentaunce taken god iuſtice muſt geue remiſsiō ſo ought purgatory argument nothyng worth frith firſt part haue oftē proued falſe repentaunce full payment ſatiſfaction ſinne dyed chriſt vayne notwithſtandyng hee graunt firſt part true neither felowes ſhal able ſolute argument whyle lyue becauſe ſhort let v paſſe ouer aunſwere whiche xiij chapter ſolutyng argument hee raſtell groundeth hym two lye firſte god neuer geueth remiſsion except ſee v conuenient cauſe counterpayſyng hys iuſtice frithwhat cauſe founde man brought vnto hym ſicke palſie ſaydthere bee cauſe v may deſerue forgeuenes ſinne luke 23 good comfort ſonne thy ſinnes forgiuen thée math ix marke ij luke v cauſe found théefe crucified hee bene vnthryft life lōg yet euen ſame day hee ſuffred chriſt partaker ioye paradiſe luke xxiij purgatory puniſhment hee ſhould haue ſuffered enormity mā ſhould ſuffer purgatory like théefe ſhould haue done purgatorybut went death life neuer came purgatory wherfore may conclude mā ſhall come cauſe pray doth paule aſſigne touching redēptiō remiſſion ſinne forſooth yt wretched ſinners enemyes god rom v rom 5 god mere mercy ſayth paule whē enemyes lye bryngeth aunſwere ſo confuſed intricate long onely fooliſhnes ſolute alſo much loſt labour coſt rehearſe wherfore let paſſe euery child ſhall raſtels ignorauncy eaſely ſolute ſith foūdation firſt felow fell downe beſought ſaying haue pacience pay thée would went caſt priſon till ſhould pay debt whē felowes ſaw done ſory came told vnto lord happened lord called hym ſayd vnto deuill ſeruaunt forgaue thée debt becauſe y• praydeſt méete alſo yt thou ſhouldeſt haue cōpaſſion thy felow euen pitie thée lord wroth deliuered gaylers till ſhould paye due hym lykewiſe ſhall heauenly father doe ded v world muſt nedes haue conuerſation men therfore hath god appointed • hée thou ſhalt doe profite thy neighbour tamyng thy fleſh paule teſtifieth epheſ 2 worke made ephe 2 chriſt ieſu good woorkes 5 ſo profitable thy neighbour alſo teſtimonie vnto thée mē may know thou art right ſonne thy heauē ly father chriſte vnto thy neighbour euen heauenly father gaue chriſt vnto v profit ſhould haue ther onely profite likewiſe y• ſhouldeſt thy good workes hauing reſpect cōmodities thou ſhalt haue euer attendyng charitie wealth profite thy neighbour thou wilt yet obiect ſée great profite ſhall haue aunſwere aunſwere obiection wouldeſt y• haue firſt chriſt geuen thée fréely haſt thou thinges thy wiſedome righteouſnes halowyng redemption cor art thou made 1 cor 1 inheritour god felowheyre commaundeth thée let lone reſidue well agréeth paule ephe 35 ephe 2 2 ſaying grace ye made ſafe fayth commeth ſelues yt gift god cōmeth workes leſt man ſhould boaſt ſelfe loe ſayth ſaluatiō yt gift accordyng ſinnes powreth mercy ſo plenteouſly vppon v alſo forgeue v iniquity ſhould ſuch purgatory purge tormēt ſely ſoules ſpecially ſith geuen wilt thou call ſhrewed 41 creditour whiche hath fréely forgeuē debtour yet caſt priſon ſame debt thinke euery man would ſay maner▪ god hath forgeuē v ſinnes therfore wil puniſh v purgatory pleaſure whether hee would forgeue fauour compaſſion forgaue hath forgeuen hee doth vnrighteouſly puniſh debtour albeit man repente forgeuyng afterward ſue debt yet god neuer repēt ſelfe mercyable gift rom xi rom 11 therefore neuer torment v treſpaſſes ſuch paynefull purgatory thus haue confuted raſtell argumentes alſo ſolutions writeth falſe agaynſt scripture furthermore haue brought proue cā ſuch purgatory l argumētes grounded scripture néede mā might make thouſand clergy ſhould able auoyde one thinke ſome mē wonder cōcluſiō iohn frith agaynſt raſtels booke haue scripture ſo full ſide becauſe certaine mē lord rocheſter syr thomas scripture go proue purgatory ſure scripture contrary vnto ſelfe therfore neceſſary examine textes bring purpoſe markyng proceſſe goeth cōmeth ſhal eaſely perceaue truth theſe ij men haue bene piteouſly deceaued firſt aunſwere vnto hath maner nothyng tooke lord rocheſter although handle ſuttelly ſoeuer aunſwered parte ſhalbe touched fully conuinced third whiche ſhall ſeuerall booke agaynſt lord rocheſter ¶ thus endeth firſt booke ſecond booke aunwere vnto syr thomas maiſter begynneth begynneth pitifully ſely ſoules purgatory maketh wayle lamēt heare world waxe ſo faynte fayth chriſt mā ſhould neede proue purgatory chriſtē mē mā could found would ſo great thyng ſo fully faſtly beleued vndoubted article xv hundred yeare begyn ſtaggar ſtand doubt c verely thinketh foule faute frith ſo ſore ſtomble euen firſt great blot ſhould compelled good authoritie cut iiij hundred foreſayd nūber onely proue purgatory 400 yeare chriſt neither beleued article yt fayth yet vndoubted truth muſt cut iiij hundred yeare alſo bryng witneſſe neither time beleued article yt fayth yet vndoubted truth thē thinke ye would ſuppoſe man ſomewhat way proue god grace auſten foure hundred yere chriſt yet time fully faſtly beleued article fayth yet fully faſtly beleued bee true hee ſelfe writeth enchiridion maner ſpeakyng purgatory expounded place paul 1 cor 3 taken 1 cor 3 word fire purgatory temptation tribulation added theſe wordes 69 chapter incredible ſuch thyng ſhuld alſo chaūce life whether ſo may queſtioned c theſe woordes may well perceaue auſten doubted purgatory counted article yt fayth neither yet vndoubted truth bene article ye faith vndoubted truth would hee haue ſayd poteſt etiā queri ſay may queſtioned doubted moued thoſe holy father vſed make queſtions doubtes article fayth among thē ſelues neither yet ſuch thing vndoubted true rom 4 vſed diſpute whether chriſte dyed ſinnes roſe agayne iuſtificatiō onely beleued beſide occaſion hée wrote booke entitled enchiridion one laurētius chriſtē man inſtantly required auſten would write forme belefe whiche hée might continually beare hand whereunto ſhould ſticke ʋpō wrote auſten litle booke commaundeth hym fully faſtly beleue theſe more wordes purgatory ſayth may queſtioned doubted moued whether ſuch place haue playne euidence none article yt fayth auſtens much deceaued accomptyng hys tyme foure hūdred yeare chriſt neither yet vndoubted truth ſo may men ſée ſore deceaued ſet ſand euen firſt brunte begynnyng viage ſecond reaſon hath proue purgatory miſcreauntes idolater turkes saracenes paynimes haue euer moſt part thought beleued more ſecond reaſon bodyes deceaſed ſoules ſuch neither deadly dampned wretch euer ſide ſo good offence done world haue deſerued puniſhment ſuffered ſuſtained purged puniſhed payne death ere euer admitted vnto wealth reſt ſo muſt nedes purgatory aūſwere lawfull require frith wiſedome man ſo wiſe counted would wiſh litle wit thinke maketh falſe fond argument wiſeman graunt good argumēt yt turkes saracenes paynimes iewes beleue true ergo muſt beleue true ſhewe like argument turkes saracenes paynimes iewes beleue haue yt right chriſt damned beleue chriſt therfore true ſhal turne fayth becauſe beleue deceaued thinke man ſo fooliſh graūt haue reaſō hold muſt argue maner miſcreauntes infidel iohn frith amē deth more argument named beleue purgatory belefe true therfore muſt beleue purgatory foloweth argument ſomewhat formally might put profe minor belefe beleuyng purgatory true thyng ſhall neuer able proue haue ſuch confidence truth ſide take vpon proue negatiue cut̄ belefe true cōcernyng purgatory theſe miſcreauntes iohn frith proueth negatiue true beleue purgatory beleue purgatory v chriſten beleue fallē truth vtterly dāned thinke purgatory ſelues wherin ſhalbe purged puniſhed vntill haue made full ſatiſfactiō ſinnes committed falſe neither turkes saracenes paynimes iewes whiche beleue chriſt haue euer ſhall enter purgatory dāned wretch becauſe beleue ieſu chriſt iohn 3 ſith iohn 3 deceaued haue purgatory damned many beleue ala blindnes argue muſt folow blynd right way diſputeth naturall raſtell argumentes frō reaſon muſt purgatory diſputation continueth leafe halfe raſtell tooke booke ſo apparent reaſons diſcloſed agaynſt raſtell begynneth scripture maner ſemeth probable likely good kyng acceptable thée ezechias wept great cryeng theſe wordes text cā perceaue text great ſinner rather contrary ſayth hee walked lorde truth perfite hart hath done thyng pleaſaunt acceptable lord therfore nothyng lyke hee ſhould feare purgatory neither yet hell thou wilt peraduēture aſke wept feare purgatory wepe alſo aſke queſtion queſtion maſter ſhew minde chriſt dyd onely wepe feared ſo ſore ſweat written gene 42 si quid aduerſitatis acciderit ei terra ad quam pergitis deducetis canos meos cum dolore ad inferos euill chaūce vnto ſonne beniamin lād whether go ſhall bryng myne hoore heares prophetes ye moſt part pſalmes hymnes ſonges prayſe make firſt ende verſe expounde laſt laſt expounde firſt obſerueth rule ſhall vnderſtand much scripture although hee ignoraunt hebrue doth place full well expounde ſelfe without imagination purgatory conferre firſt part ye verſe vnto laſt ſhall eaſely perceaue firſt part halfe verſe lord doth kill lord doth kill rayſe expoūdeth halfe verſe ſhe ſayth hee leadeth downe hell ſo place kill leade downe hell one thing likewiſe ſecond part halfe verſe quicken agayne bryng agayne one thyng man ſuperſtitious hée dare vnderſtand thyng figurately ſpoken may verifie vpon god rayſed naturall death lazarus iohn xj beit man iohn 11 deny ſence good text may ſo vnderſtād yet minde ſhal go nye vnto pure truth expounde thus lord doth kill quickē agayne leadeth downe hell bringeth agayne hee bryngeth men extreme affliction miſerie whiche ſignified death hell turneth hys face vnto maketh folow hym well agréeth 78 pſalme ſpeaketh pſal 78 child iſrael figure elect church congregation theyr yeares paſſed ouer perpetuall trouble whē deſtroyed killed • hen god ſaith killeth doth quicken againe meanyng therof ſought hym turned beſought buſely meaneth firſt killed temporal death death made ſéeke hym wrapped extreme affliction perpetuall trouble ſore ſcourged whē brake cōmaundements yet turned mercyfull face vnto hym finally haue pure vnderſtādyng place note wordes iij child daniell 3 daniell 3 whiche caſt fornace fire yet preſerued frō death thorough mighty hand god theyr wordes ſong benedicite anania azaria miſaell domino laudate ſuperexaltate eum ſecula quia eruit no de inferno ſaluos fecit de manu mortis liberauit no de medio ardentis flammae de medio ignis eruit no blyſſe ye anania azaria miſaell lord prayſe aduaūce euer hath plucked v hell hath ſaued v frō power death hath deliuered true interpretatiō scripture v middeſt burnyng flāme hath plucked v frō middes fire may ſée ſame maner ſpeakyng laſt ende expoundeth begynnyng theſe childrē ſay god hath plucked hell yet neither dāned purgatory dead next part verſe expoundeth meaning ſayth hath ſaued v hand power death may ye know bee plucked hell ſaued power death one thyng ſay god hath deliuered burnyng flamme hee hath plucked middes fire one ſenſe euery child may well perceiue therfore blame ſo foule fault buſie ſeyng vnderſtandeth phraſe manner ſpeache scripture bryngeth hee prophet zachary ſayth tu quo que ſanguine teſtamenti tui eduxiſti vinctos zacharie tuos de lacu quo non erat aqua thou haſt bloud thy teſtament brought thy bounden priſoners pitte lake water hell redemption lymbo patrum ſoules reſt wherfore appeareth clerely thoſe priſoners whiche hee brought payne hee brought onely purgatory text ſpoken zachary 9 frith full aunſwere text néeded bring authoritie zacharie 9 lord rocheſter agaynſt hym hee expoundeth place pſalme 66 purgatory whiche pſal 66 ſayth tranſiuimus per ignem aquam adduxiſti no refrigeriū haue gone thorough fire water thou haſt brought v coleneſſe text pſalme ſerue purgatory ſayth fire water lord rocheſter doth affirme bringeth alſo origine confirme place zacharie ſerue whiche ſayth water ſo muſt néedes bee ouerſene origene rocheſter bee able wey vp might ſay vnto thē rocheſter agree ſhould firſt agrée thē ſelues would ſhape aūſwere howbeit know part ſo ſure confute proue neither place ſpeaketh thyng paynfull purgatory deſcribe lord rocheſters authoritie ſhall differred vntill thyrd part whiche ſhalbe ſeuerall booke agaynſt hym place verely approueth ſauyng prophete zachary vnderſtand purgatory ſheweth vertue chriſtes redemption bloud redemed captiues priſoners ſay hee foūd bound ſtrōg bondes ſinne euerlaſtyng damnatiō ſubiectes vnto deuil extreme enemyes god calleth hee verely becauſe choſen chriſt ieſu begynnynge worlde hym ſhould enioy euerlaſtyng inheritaunce heauen called bounde priſoners surely becauſe captiues boūde impriſoned vnder deuill ſinne adā committed rom rom 5 v ſayth deliuered thē pitte water forſooth euen much ſay hee deliuered hell eternall damnation thou wilt obiectiō aunſwere therunto happely ſay hee deliuered hell eternall damnation priſoners ſay yt ſhalbe ſaued neuer came aunſwere ſhould without doubt haue gone thether haue bene dāned perpetually except chriſt death deliuered loſed therefore ſayth scripture chriſt deliuereth v hell becauſe ſaueth deliuereth v come el ſhould ſurely enter euer alſo common maner ſpeach among v man ſhould go priſon debt ſuch matter one frendes come yt meane ſeaſon pacified aduerſaries payeth debt may well ſay hath deliuered man priſon although hee came ſhould haue gone thether likewiſe ſay ſuch mā hath deliuered frend galowes meane ready hanged deliueraūce late meane deliuered hee ſhould hanged furthermore mā might queſtion maſter bee bold aſke whether chriſt haue redemed looſed deliuered bloud teſtament thinke would aunſwere yea ſhould aſke whence hath deliuered ſure ſo ignoraunt ſay chriſte hath deliuered purgatory euen hath deliuered eternall death damnation ſo hath chriſte deliuered v pytte wherin water ſay frō hell euerlaſtyng damnation yt hell ready although bound vnder ſinne ready caſt therein becauſe ſhould enter hell pure vnderſtandyng texte might diſpute wt true plaine expoſition prophet zachary hell limbus patrum becauſe wilbe ſhort poſſible deferre yt vntil occaſiō yt may reaſon hym ſomewhat large place alſo old teſtament putteth purgatory quyte queſtion ſayth playner place whiche booke machebees make mention machabeus deuoute remembraunce prayour aſmoſe ſacrifice done ſoules good holy mā iudas machabeus gathered money among people buy ſacrifice withall offered vp ſoules dead battaile ſhift finde surely ſhameleſſe ſhift sore ſpo •… fayne take talkyng ſhote anker alway finde ſtorme ſo great ſee ſhyppe goeth wracke firſt vſe ſet ſome falſe gloſſe vnto text helpe fall ſhameles boldnes let deny scripture place whiche hee reciteth frith written 2 macha 12 ſay 2 mach 12 truth yt booke ſufficiēt authoritie make article fayth neither admitted canō hebrues obiecteth church hath allowed holy doctours hierome auſtine ſuch aunſwere hieromes mynde opened vnto v epiſtle wrote yt prouerbes salomō wordes theſe sicut iudith tobie machabeorum libros legit quidem co eccleſia ſed inter canonicas scripturas non recipit ſic haec duo volumina legat ad aedificationem plebis non ad authoritatem eccleſiaſticorum dogmatum confirmandum lyke church bokes machabees canon yt hebrues doth read bookes iudith tobias machabées receaueth amōg canonicall scripture euen ſo let read theſe twoo bookes meaneth booke sapience eccleſiaſticus vnto edifieng people confirme doctrine church therby nothyng lyke auſten ſhould diſſent hierome one tyme yea hierome lyued auſten therfore church could admit ſuch bookes either auſtens tyme tyme hierome ſhould haue knowne ſo may gather auſten allow theſe bookes el ſay churche hath allowed may vnderſtād haue allowed receaued canonicall scripture make hierome lyar thus muſt vnderſtād haue receaued read edifying ye people confirme doctrine church article fayth thereby according hieromes expoſitiō may ſée ſhote anker called ſo ſtrōg ſtormes waues moue deny booke receaued church read ſhew hierome entent receaued read proue article faith therby onely order maner liuyng therafter ſuch poyntes repugnaunt vnto canonicall scripture yet mā pleaſure let ſlyppe ſhote anker take ſeas furious wyndes frothy 〈◊〉 waues wil neuer ſtrike ſayle ſo ſtrong ſhyp ſo well ballaunced caſe booke machabées good authority eſay yet proue fury paynefull purgatorye therby ſpeaketh one word neither fire payne ſpeaketh ſacrifice offred dead yt might loſed frō ſinnes becauſe reſurrectiō yt ded may wel without paine fire concluſion meaning true expoſition machabees touching purgatory bare naked good offer ſacrifice dead may looſed ſinnes ergo ſenſible fire doth puniſhe holy choſen people god ſure child may perceaue argument naught beſides bee doubted 〈◊〉 whether iudas wel offering ſacrifice therfore ought fooliſh preſumption ſolow facte vntill knowe accepted peraduenture thou wilt ſay déede commended ſayd text ſayth becauſe conſidered godlynes entred ſléepe death good fauour layd vp ſtore therefore remēbraunce pray dead holy wholeſome may looſed ſinnes aunſwere perſons whiche ſlayne battayl prayer ſacrifice made founde haue vnder clokes oblation idol iamniam ſlaughter iewes idolatry cauſe ſlayne playne text yea hoſt prayſed right iudgement god theſe men ſo ſlayne damned law deut vij whiche ſayth image deutro 7 god thou ſhalt burne fire ſée thou couet ſiluer gold yt take vnto thée leſt iudas machabeus deceaued hys ſacrifice thou ſnared therewith abomination vnto lord thy god bryng therfore abomination vnto thine houſe leſt thou dāned thing vtterly defie abhorre thyng muſt deſtroyed may euidētly perceaue albeit iudas dyd thyng good mynde yet deceaued ſacrifice could nothyng helpe ſith damned law entred ſlepe godlyneſſe ſuppoſed furthermore euident 〈◊〉 iewes ſacrifices ſinnes liued leuit 4 5 6 c knew theſe ſacrifices would extende ſelues vnto ſinnes dead cō maunded vnder payne curſing ſhould adde nothyng vnto word god deut 12 ʋerely deut 12 lyke prieſtes euen tyme ſought owne profite abuſed ſacrifices deceaued ſimple people alſo ſayth money 4 ſēt buy ſacrifices ſhoulde offered ſinne ſlayne knoweth euery chriſten maner ſacrifices offeryngs nothyng figure chriſt ſhould offered ſinne people chriſtes death ſacrifices ceaſed chriſt came ſacrifices oblation ceaſed thou ſhouldeſt offer calfe purge thy ſinne thou doubt iniurious vnto bloud chriſt thou thought bloud ſufficiēt wouldeſt thou ſéeke ſacrifice thy ſinne yea go 5 one ſacrifice old teſtamēt purged tooke away ſinne bloud oxē goates take away ſinne heb x heb 〈◊〉 ſacrifices thē offered ſignifie chriſt ſhould come made ſacrifice v ſhuld purge ſinne euer ſacrifices oblation inſtitute god yet could take away ſinne onely ſacrifice cā take away ſinne onely ſacrifice made chriſt ſignified chriſt bl • ſhould take away madnes come braynes thinke oblation whiche ordained owne imagination ſhould take away ſinne iudas gathered ſuch 6 offeryng old teſtamēt ſhould folow muſt doe ſo know chriſt come oblation ceaſed hym ſhall become iewes go backe agayne ſhadow ceremonie ſith haue body ſignificatiō holieſt men haue fallen whiche chriſt ieſue iudas holy man might yet amiſſe caſe dyd well ſhall therfore ſtraight wayes worke ground article fayth dauid holy man yet committed murther aduoutry ſhal without enſearchyng scripture ſtreightwayes folow example abraham holy man commaū ded god offer owne ſonne ſhall offer child therfore gedſon ioſue deſtroyed vnfaythfull kyngs ſpiritualty theſe xij thouſād drachma ſhyne ſo bright eye yt without cādle lanterne ſpectacles haue eſpyed article fayth may conſider haue taken text xij thouſand drachmes epiſtle ſoule maſſes god act xv ſacrifice actes 15 iudas ceremony ſignified yt chriſt ſhould bloud raſtell quench ſinnes ergo keepeth coūteth ceremony neceſſary article fayth doth captiue ſelf vnder law tempteth god ſpeake ſharpely yet go litle nere vnto 8 iudas hym ſelfe beleued yt purgatory tyme ſcholemē ſay tyme olde teſtament purgatory old teſtament purgatory scholemen graūt themſelues onely place reſt called limbus patrum wherfore pitiouſly deceaued proue purgatory textes old teſtament ſith ſay themſelues purgatory tyme finally cā finde place 9 ſelfe properly cōfuteth phantaſticall purgatory doth ſame texte whiche ſticke ſo ſore imaginyng ſtabliſheth purgatory text ſaith maner except hee hoped ſlayne ſhould riſe agayn ſhould ſéeme voyde vayne pray dead fayne purgatory thē muſt text néedes falſe caſe dead ſhould riſe agayne ſayth text voyde vayne pray dead ſhould riſe agayne purgatory wherein ſhould purged puniſhed meane ſeaſon vayne pray deliuer payne rather frutefull neceſſary although ſhould neuer ryſe agayne therfore text authoritie impoſſible ſhould purgatory neither text iudgement better vndermine purgatory make fall peraduenture deſire know mynde place ſhould expoūd vnto iudasment declaration meanyng iudas machabeus offeryng hys ſacrifice dead oblatiō ſith thought purgatory yt foreſayd text doth well ſpecifie ʋerely thinke iudas beleued ſhould reſurrection text prayſed hym ſaying thinkyng well deuoutly reſurrection among iewes many beleued reſurrection fleſh beleued yet ſo rude ignoraūt thought ſhould ryſe obtayne carnall kyngdome haue enemyes ſubdued vnder without rebellion thereto ſticke iewes vnto day moſt lyke ſhould meanyng ſhall ryſe agayne poſſeſſe land peace theſe men ſlaine fauour god becauſe haue contrary law deut deut 7 vij take idol oblation therfore beſt ſend ſacrifice vnto ieruſalem pacifie wrath god towardes leſt whē riſe againe lord ſhould ſend ſome plague amongeſt v trāſgreſſiō committed lyuyng mā better iudas machabeus thought purgatory geſſe wel cōtent admit playne inough thought ſacrifice could helpe thē ſhould riſe agayne doth fully deſtroy purgatory ſayth voyde vayne pray dead excepte ſhould ryſe agayne euen much ſay vnto hym hath witte prayer ſacrifices good riſen agayne death el vayne praye although ſhould neuer ryſe agayn example ſay man ſhall neuer obtayne purpoſe except ſhould ſue king grace euen much ſay mā hath wytte ſhall neuer obtaine purpoſe hath ſued kynges hyghnes maſter goeth ieſt like proued inſipient countenaunce ſay booke machabées autētike becauſe receaued yt canon hebrues ſayth reaſon may alſo denye booke sapience proue ſelues inſipientes verely admitte booke sapience true autentike feare go nye proue hym inſipient grauntyng purgatory read 45 argument agaynſt raſtell iudge whether ſay true hetherto haue let ſlyp ſhoteanker haue runne sea hym grauntyng pleaſure booke ſhould good authority eſay church holy doctours wiſe man ſuppoſeth ſo good authoritie onely ſée concluſion might brought vpon graūted man would require iohn frithes iudgement y• bookes machabees iudgement concerning booke would ſhortly aunſwere either booke falſe authoritie el chriſt apoſtles holy doctours scholemen therto falſe without authoritie admitteth prayer ſacrifice done dead yea alſo affirmeth holy whole ſome ſuch ſinnes dā ned law god déede mortall doth agaynſt word god yea alſo agaynſt cōmon conſent mē booke doth ſo admitteth prayer ſacrifice bée done dead ſlayne battayle theyr offence yea alſo damned law deut 7 conclude ſelues ye thinke booke thus much hath brought proue purpoſe old teſtament thinke ye ſée ſufficiently aunſwered entendeth proue hys purgatory good ſubſtaunciall authoritie new teſtament alſo firſt let v conſider ſayth maſter wordes bleſſed apoſtle euangeliſt iohn 1 iohn 5 ſayth eſt peccatum ad mortem non dico vt pro eo roget quis ſayth hee ſome ſinne vnto death byd man ſhould pray ſinne interpreter agree vnderſtād deſperatiō impenitency damnable ſinners deſperation impenitēce though saint iohn would ſay departe world impenitent deſpayre prayer made neuer ſtand hym ſtede appeareth clearely iohn meaneth whiche dye ſuch caſe hee would men ſhould pray becauſe prayer ſuch ſoules may profitable profite man take beyng heauen needeth beyng hell boteth wherefore appeareth ſuch prayer helpeth onely purgatory thou muſt therfore nedes graunt except thou deny iohn text written 1 iohn 5 frith 1 iohn 5 ſayth ſinne vnto death byd man ſhall pray place doth vnderſtād word death temporall death taketh pleaſure deſire hym looke two lynes aboue ſnatch one péece text faſhion rehearſe whole text ye ſhal heare myne aunſwere text man perceaue brother doth ſinne ſinne vnto yt death let aſke ſhall geue hym lyfe ſinne vnto death ſome ſinne vnto death bid mā
