euerlaſtyng death therfore ſhewe vnderſtandyng yt text better interpreter deſire none chriſt ſelfe ſayd vnto phariſeis euery blaſphemy ſhall forgeuen yt blaſphemy againſt holy ghoſt iohn calleth ſinne vnto death ſhall neuer forgeuen giltie vnto euerlaſtyng damnation marke iij ſinne blaſphemie verely marke 3 yt declareth marke ſaying blaſphemy ſin againſt holy ghoſt • ſayd vncleane ſpirite yt yt ſinne vnto death euerlaſtyng ſinne ſhould neuer forgeuen proueth ſo euidently vnto thē miracle done yt ſpirite god could deny yet hard obſtinate hart euen knowyng contrary ſayd deuill within hym theſe phariſeis dyed forth lyued peraduenture many yeares notwithſtā ding apoſtles prayed theſe phariſeis while yet lyuing ſinne ſhould neuer haue bene forgeuen truth dyed impenitencie deſperation frute ſinne ſinne ſelfe ſée ye meanyng pure vnderſtanding text ſinne vnto death agaynſt holy ghoſt man perceaue brother ſinne ſinne vnto death againſt holy ghoſt let aſke ſhall geue life let pray vnto god brother ſinne ſhalbe forgeuen ſée brother ſinne ſinne vnto death agaynſt holy ghoſt let neuer pray boteth ſo text vnderſtand prayer lyfe imagineth euen prayer brother lyuing v notwithſtanding ſinne lightly knowne excepte perſon knowledge hym ſelfe el ſpirite god opē vnto v therfore may pray men except haue euident knowledge haue ſo offended rehearſed text taken wherwith laboureth proue purgatory ſay wordes apoca 5 iohn apoc 5 haue heard ſayth euery creature heauen vppon earth vnder earth sea thynges theſe haue heard ſay benediction honour glory power euer ſitting throne vnto lambe creature heauen hee meaneth aungels creature vpon note earth meaneth men creature vnder earth meaneth ſoules purgatory creature sea hee meaneth men ſayle sea text vnderſtand onely frith aungels men alſo heauen earth euē beaſtes fiſhes wormes creature thinke theſe creature prayſe lord taketh creature vnder yt earth ſoules purgatory take 〈◊〉 doth agree maner creature vnder yt earth wormes vermine draweth text maketh creature ſea ſignifie men ſayling sea ſay creature sea ſignifie fiſhes ſuch thyngs iohn textment euen playnly maner thynges geue prayſe vnto god lambe yea dare bold adde euen deuils damned ſoules compelled prayſe hym iuſt puniſhment commendeth puyſaunt power righteouſnes neither néedeſt thou wōder thinke new thyng dauid 148 byddeth serpentes beaſtes byrdes prayſe lord alſo written dani iij paule ſayth rom 8 maner a▪ true expoſition scripture creature long redemption prayſe god yea mourne laſt day yet come elect child god might enter reſt ſhall alſo thoſe creature deliuered frō corruptiō bondage libertie glory child god iudge chriſten reader whiche ſentence ſtandeth moſt scripture glory god doth bleſſed apoſtle peter appeareth actes ij ſay sauiour chriſte wiſe quem deus ſuſcitauit ſolutis doloribus inferni theſe woordes ſhewed paynes hell loſed thoſe paynes paynes damned ſoules limbo patrum payne ergo payne purgatory looſed ala ſhall ſay frith maner compelled ſay mā wandreth wilfull blindneſſe el poſſible ſhould erre ſo far bring text hys purpoſe woordes peter theſe ye men iſraell heare theſe wordes ieſus nazareth man ſet foorth god wyth power wonder token god hath done hym among ſelues know deliuered purpoſed counſell foreknowledge god receyued hym handes wicked ye crucifyed kylled god hath rayſed diſſoluing paynes death impoſible ſhould ſubdued ſtead theſe wordes purpoſely corrupteth ſence scripture paynes death ſetteth paynes hell moſt like euē purpoſed deceit albeit mā would take payne read gréeke yet looked vpon tranſlation hys olde frende companion eraſmus would haue taught haue ſayd ſolutis doloribus mortis diſſoluing paynes death according gréeke woordes luke wrote theſe actes gréeke tongue albeit old tranſlation vſeth thys worde infernus diuerſly taken ſcripture death graue hell yet place maiſter wythout excuſe calleth hell engliſh tongue albeit woord ſelf indifferent latine yet indifferent engliſh engliſh man taketh thys woord hell eyther death graue maiſter himſelf firſt tranſlateth text falſely falſely deſcāteth vppon scripture calling hell deſcanteth falſe ground calleth hell death purgatory peter brought theſe wordes purpoſe proue yt chriſt riſen death power hys father meaning god father dyd rayſe hys sonne chriſt notwythſtanding ſorowfull paynes panges ſuffred vnto yt death impoſſible chriſt ſhould vtterly ſubdued death thys text proueth purgatory proueth maiſter hyred ſpiritualty defend purgatory beſides proctour purgatory ſhould ſerue purgatory wiſe man wil graunt whē ſéeeth proceſſe text ſhould proue nothing chriſt ſhould lye paynes purgatory vntill god hys father holp paynes▪ ſpeaketh chriſtes paynes man deny read text fond opinion fayne chriſt without ſinne ſhould tormented paynes purgatory bleſſed apoſtle paule 1 cor 3 firſt epiſtle corinthian third chapter ſpeaking ſauiour chriſt foundation fayth ſaluation ſayth man builde vpon foundation gold ſiluer precious ſtones wood hay ſtrawe euery man worke ſhall made open day lord ſhall declare fire ſhalbe ſhewed fire ſhall proue maner thyng euery man worke would faine proue purgatory man worke hath builded thereon abide ſhall haue reward man worke burne ſhall ſuffer harme ſhalbe ſafe yet fire finally concludeth thys woord fyre muſt néedes ſignifie fyre purgatorye conſidereth order f • ith proces text ſhall eaſely perceiue thys man erreth text ſpeaketh preacher blameth corrinthians made ſuch ſectes diſſentions among ſelues one ſayd paules man held hys ſide ſayd peter man thirde ſticke apollo ſo foorth euen frier dayes one ſect holdeth fraunces dominike thyrd auſten c paule rebuketh theſe ſectes called perſons carnall commaunding take chriſt theyr head cleaue onely apollo peter paule ſayth miniſters woord▪ euery mā according gyfte geuen hym god one leſſe paule planted apollo watred paule ſet corinthian ground chriſtes fayth came apollo preached chriſt comforted abide way walked howbeit onely god made proſper woord gaue encreaſe neuertheles euery ſhal laboreth much god 〈◊〉 nyard ſhall receaue much c man ſhall receaue according labour preach much ſhall reward preach litle therafter ſhall rewarded god workmē preach hys worde god huſbandry muſt till dreſſe declaring woord perpetuall god become god building thorough grace god hath geuen whome muſt frame ſo couch word god may make temple liuing ſtones lyke wiſe woorkemaiſter haue layd foundation firſt beganne preach chriſt commeth buildeth vpon foū dation entendyng inſtruct wayes chriſt let euery mā take hede buildeth preach vnto man cā lay foundation layed already buildyng preachyng leneth onely pointe principall ſtone declare vnto chriſt hath done builde foundation builde gold ſiluer precious ſtone gold ſiluer precious ſtones man preach purely word god likened gold ſiluer precious ſtones becauſe theſe conſumed matteriall fire rather made pure euen ſo pure word god ſuffreth neither hurt damage ſpirituall fire temptation perſecution el man build vpon buyld wood haye ſtubble foūdation woode hay ſtubble man good entent yet thorough ignoraunce preach teach ſticke vnto ceremony mēs tradition although ſéeme neuer ſo glorious ſuch thynges groūded scripture cyprian taught defended cyprian rebaptiſe hym baptiſed fallen hereſie yea many byſhops conſented vnto hym yet ſurely great errour woode haye ſtubble cā endure fire temptation lyght god word euery man worke ſhalbe declared day ſhall open albeit proſpere ſeaſon darke perceiued yet whē day commeth light god worde ſhalbe eſpyed iudged day ſhal open ſhalbe reuelated fire fire ſhall proue euery man worke fire ſignifieth temptation tribulation perſecution c whiche ſhall proue euery man workes man worke hee hath builded doe abyde euery man work tryed fire fire word man hath preached abyde aſſaultes temptatiōs token ſurely grounded scripture god ſhall preacher receiue reward man worke burnt preacher wordes abyde tryall light vaniſh away token well grounded scripture ſo ſhall ſuffer hurt ſhalbe great croſſe vexation preacher hart hath bene ſo deceiued hym ſelfe hath alſo ledde errour notwithſtādyng ſhalbe ſaued becauſe fayth foundation chriſt ignoraunce ſhalbe pardoned ſith erreth malicious purpoſe good zeale yet ſhall fire ſhall greue hart ſée laboured vayne hee muſt deſtroy ſame ignoraunce preached proceſſe pure vnderſtandyng text man graūteth theſe wordes foundation laying wordes figuratiuely ſpoken foundation buildyng gold ſiluer precious ſtones wood haye ſtubble figuratiuely ſpoken cā ſuffer word fire ſo taken finde word fire ſoeuer proceſſe plante purgatory without conſideratiō yet iudgement might well perceaue paules owne wordes tooke worde fire material fire groſſely imagine proceded allegory ſpake figuratiuely paule ſaith ſhalbe ſaued ſo thorough fire marke well wordes ſayth ſhalbe ſaued fire thorough fire ſignifiyng ſhalbe great grief veratiō vnto theſe wordes paule child may perceaue ment furthermore ſo ſtifnecked bow yt truth ſtill perſeuer owne phantaſies faynyng purgatory place thē boldly ſay vnto ſhall man enter onely preacher place paul onely ſpeaketh affirmeth preachyng learnyng ſhall ſo proued thorough fire ſuch preacher ſhall ſaued yet thorough fire therfore may temporaltie good comfort promiſe texte ſhall neuer haue hurt painfull purgatory doth bleſſed sauiour math 12 ſelfe ſay certaine ſinne man may ſo cō mit agaynſt holy ghoſt ſhall neuer remitted▪ forgeuen neither world world come lorde ſayth blaſphemy agaynſte holy ghoſt ſhall forgeuē neither world world come geueth v cleare knowledge ſinnes ſome ſhall bee forgeuen world ſome world come although argument frith sophiſme yet neither one rule sophiſtry proue ſubtile ſophiſme argument yet one sophiſter ſo fooliſh graunt ſhould ſay vnto mine enemy would neither forgeue lōg lyued death becauſe hee done ſome haynous treſpaſſe would men coūt hym worſe thē made would ſay frith forgeue enemy long lyueth death ergo ſome mē forgeue enemyes death ſay forgeue hym neither life death meane wil neuer forgeue make addiction becauſe hée ſhould fooliſhnes looke ſuch forgeueneſſe thus foloweth argument remiſſiō ſinnes lyfe well ſhall forgeuen thys world world come ergo ſhall neuer forgeuen euen ſo doth holy euangeliſt marke expounde theſe woordes chriſt thyrd chapter mathew ſaith chap 12 ſpeaketh agaynſt holy ghoſt ſhal neuer haue forgeuen world world come marke expoundeth thus marke 3 ſpeaketh blaſphemy agaynſt holy ghoſt hath remiſſion euer giltie vnto euerlaſtyng damnation thys haue ſpoken ſufficiently ſoluting text 1 ioh 5 ſinne alſo text vnderſtand neither affirmeth scripture place ſinne forgeuen thys lyfe ſayth ready ye know time lorde ſhall come ſhould ſay lyfe remiſſion full mercy labour therfore attayne thys lyfe ſuch forgeuenes euen lord findeth thee ſo ſhall iudge thée hys next laſt argument ſcripture chriſt ſayth rehearſed math 12 xij matthew men ſhall yeld reckenyng euery idle worde ſhall thys preſent lyfe wotteth euery man reckoning vnderſtand puniſhment therefore ſhal hell much leſſe heauen therfore el purgatory verily haue heard patrone frith ſo vnprofitably defendeth hys clyent yet man geueth himſelfe ſuch proper trippes caſt himſelfe except went doth quyte ouerthrow hym ſelfe betray vtterly deſtroy part would ſéeme fauour thys text maketh agaynſt hym brought ſéemeth make wordes mathew theſe tell euery idle woord men ſpeake ſhall yéeld reckoning day iudgement leaueth full craftely let v reaſon thys text reckoning vnderſtood puniſhment ſinne maiſter ſayth himſelf thys reckoning ſhall vppon day dome ergo puniſhment ſinne day dome either vpon el day dome god firſt puniſh reckon punyſhe new ſo purgatory quite excluded more argument purgatory quyte excluded euer imagined purgatory put iudgement chriſt commeth iudgement ceaſeth purgatory conſent neyther prayer ſuffrage time helpe ſo hath maſter thys text geuen ſelfe proper fall may ſée ſtrong hys reaſons wil happen taketh hand defend falſhode agaynſt truth goddes woord hys reaſons make agaynſt wyſh may well know hys matter ben thing lykely would haue coloured faſhion ſith ſuch patrone ſo greatly commended conueyance wiſedome handleth matter ſo flenderly may well miſtruſt hys cauſe thys laſt reaſon grounded scripture wherwith hath laboured proue purgatory thys reaſon reckeneth vp doctours ſayth pleaſure al make touching doctoures make ſufficient aunſwer third part agaynſt lorde rocheſter thus leaueth scripture hath full vnmanerly handled endeuoureth himſelfe proue purpoſe ſome probable reaſons firſt bringeth hys old argument church erre reaſon néede aunſwer william tyndall hath declared aboundantly treatiſe goddes grace ſhall ſhortly haue church alſo may erre doth erre pope adherent church imagineth thys confirmeth hys fantaſie phantaſticall apparition ſaying haue euery country euery age apparition bene well knowne teſtified men haue ſufficient reuelation proofe purgatorye howe many haue god moſt gracious fauour appeared theyr freendes theyr death ſhewed themſelues holpen deliuered thence pilgrimage almeſdeedes prayer c ſay theſe lye much worſe maſter luther himſelfe conſenteth ſermons many ſuch apparition bee true true muſt needes purgatory playeth maſter ſuttle ſubtill sophiſter ſophiſter would deceiue men wyth fallace lyeth thys woorde true ſo ſayeth ſuch apparition true thys ſentence may taken two maner wayes one true ſuch phantaſticall apparition appeare diuers thinke man ſo foliſh graunt yet déede ſoules deuils ſo appeare delude men ſhould fall frō fayth chriſt make god owne workes truſtyng ſaued thereby ſuppoſe true ſoules purgatory ſo appeare fonde falſe agaynſt scripture eſay ſayth ſhall go quicke vnto dead ſhall enquire eſay 8 dead beleue ſuch pointes cōcerne wealth nay ſayth vnto law witnes vnto god word ſo moniſhed eſay truth bee ſought dead 8 beleue ſuch phantaſies commaūded law god enquire dead truth god abhorreth deut xviij beſides parable rich man lazarus doth vtterly condemne ſuch apparition ſoules appeare deuils rich man deſired lazarus might go warne luke 16 brethrē ſhould come place payne abrahā aunſwered moſes prophetes addyng alſo beleued would beleue although one ſhould riſe agayne tell ſo may conclude vayne ſend ſuch apparition ſoules déede ſoules ſent god verely deuils whiche come delude people withdraw chriſt furthermore men graunt appearyng samuell illuſion deuill thou ſhalt finde ſtory reg xxviij long ſith ſuch queſtion 1 kinge • 3 moued oxford thing poore man coū trey whiche ſore troubled ſuch apparition came thyng deſired go certaine pilgrymages certaine ceremony whereby ſayd ſhould deliuered innumerable torment ſuffered poore man beleued apparition ſpirite moued certeine oxford thyng ſayd truth dyd commaunded notwithſtandyng came ſo often vnto labour feare mā almoſt beſides ſelfe hee ſent oxford aſke counſell beſt bee done queſtion moued one doctour nicolas hee affirmed ſoule deuill ſhould folow fendes appetite moued kyngton affirmed ſame finally enquyred roper minde therin ſayd would looke booke looked pleaſure gaue aunſwere let alone quoth warraunt felow ſhall either hang ſelfe drowne hym ſelfe come ſome miſchief thus determined theſe men whiche great deale ſuperſtitious diſſent old doctours yea el owne scholemen yet would make v beleue ſoules ſuch ceremony might deliuered commeth ſolute thoſe two reaſons brought agaynſt purgatory supplication beggers yt whole occaſion booke marke ſlender ſolutiōs firſt reaſon purgatory pope might deliuer one ſoule hys pardon may ſame authoritie deliuer many may deliuer many may deliuer ſecond reaſon deliuer money may alſo deliuer wythout money cruel tyraunt kéepeth paynes ſo intollerable imagineth ſelfe vntill pay money firſt hee ſoluteth maner ſolution two former reaſons sith lord ſendeth thether ſatiſfaction made ſome maner ſinne pope ſhould rather agaynſt god purpoſe delyuer free chaunge maner ſatiſfaction frō payne prayer almoſe good workes done frendes ſome pointe profitable neceſſary whole corp chriſtēdome ſome good member ſame concernyng ſatiſfaction haue ſpoken ſufficiētly agaynſt raſtell frith scripture knoweth ſatiſfaction made ſinne towardes god onely bloud ſonne ieſu chriſt ſatiſfaction dyed chriſt vayne yea ſéeketh ſatiſfactiō ſinne towardes god chriſtes bloud muſt receiued repē tyng hart fayth doth deſpiſe chriſtes bloud treade vnder féete ſo firſt part more ſolution falſe ſhould argument falſe ſhut purgatory make ſatiſfaction beſides hee ſayth pope ſhould ſo deliuer ſhould deliuer free ſay nay pope deliuer mā thence vntil ſatiſfactiō made adherentes graūt therefore finde away might ſeme deliuer thē fayneth hath hand merites chriſtes paſſion merites saintes deſtribute pleaſure therfore might pope apply merites chriſtes paſſion saintes vnto theſe ſely ſoules ſo deliuer thoſe merites ar inough ſatiſfie yt ſoules purgatory ten tymes ſo many ſo ſhould pope deliuer frée chaū gyng maner ſatiſfaction payne merites chriſtes paſſion saintes ſo reaſon abated rather ſtrō ger thē howbeit ſay truth merites chriſtes paſſion onely diſtributed vnto faythfull tha • god ſpirite pope merites saintes helpe haue litle ſelues god ſhould enter iudgement pſalme 104 chriſt ſayth luke 17 chriſt ſayth haue done commaunded ſay vnprofitable ſeruauntes well agréeth parable x ʋirgins math 25 whiche could depart theyr oyle feare ſhould haue inough ſelues ſecond reaſon byteth ſomwhat therefore calleth vnreaſonable would auoyd example thys wiſe preſuppoſe pope may •• e 〈…〉 ſecond reaſon deliuer al ſoules purgatory yet therfore cruell oft leueth vnreaſonable reaſon layeth cruelty vnto blame god may vndoubtedly deliuer al ſoules thence yet leaueth thē blaſphemye ſhould alſo touch hys hye maieſtie keeping ſoule hell whence man doubteth might liſt deliuer euer aunſwere example f • ith nothing like god deliuer man neither hell purgatory ſuch one vntill hys iuſtice counterpayſed haue ſufficiently proued agaynſt raſtell obiect abſolute power aunſwer hath abſolute iuſtice well abſolute power ſo hys abſolute power nothing vntill hys abſolute iuſtice ſatiſfyed agayne ſay god hath power luſt agaynſt hys ſcripture himſelf god cānot againſt himſelfe power luſt fulfill hath promiſed vnto faythfull euerlaſting glory vnto wicked eternall damnation god hys ſcripture deliuer man hell power make himſelfe lyer ſo god neither deliuer man purgatory ſuppoſed one vntill hys iuſtice pacified pope ſayth himſelfe hath full ſatiſfaction hys hand wherby god iuſtice muſt pacified wherfore onely pope fault hath ſatiſfaction power geue till haue money god fault muſt néedes tary vntill ſatiſfaction made ſo thys reaſon ſtrong pope proued cruell tyraunt bvt yet excuſe pope ſayth meete pope • ſhould ſo quicke deliueraūce ſo ſhould geue great occaſion mē boldly fall ſinne litle care feare ſlowly ryſe agayne mete office forſooth gentle reaſon frith may quicke deliueraūce becauſe ſhould geue men occaſion ſinne one peny quyte deliuer ſpede penny offred dominickes boxe worketh great matter ye offer peny dominikes boxe aſſoone ye heare ye peny ryng boxe euen ſo ſoone ſoule heauē call quicke deliueraūce geue peny may deliuer ſoule ſhould occaſion ſinne geue peny thē ſuch occaſiō ſinne great vertue note •… p •… hath one peny more ſight cleane wypeth away occaſion ſinne furthermore redemption may done money ſhall ſtill occaſion vnto rich regard ſinne yet néed brydeled poore rich aboundaunce raygneth ſinne moſt howbeit haue ſhewed ſufficiently agaynſt raſtell feare ſinne feare purgatorye ſhall neuer come damned hell ſhould abſtaine ſinne feare pure loue haue god moſt mercifull father c commeth maiſter imagination ſhould ſay man prayer good deed help ſaith true thē could chriſtes bitter pasſion proſite v sir mine opiniō chriſtes death frith 1 haue al ſinned adam without conſent worke ioh frith declareth opinion chriſtes death 1 looſed ſinne thorough chriſt without workes deſeruinges 2 sinne come world thorow adam puniſhed wt death 2 death chriſt turned medicine cleane finiſheth ſinne 3 one man ſinne whiche adam hath condemned many men 3 one man grace chriſt hath vanquiſhed ſinne holpen many 4 one man ſinne able condemne v without workes 4 much god grace power ſaue v without workes 5 sinne thorough adam dominion ouer v 8 lyfe grace preuayleth ouer v 9 synne death haue cōdemned men 9 grace life haue ſaued men 10 thorough adam adam ſynne counted owne 10 thorough chriſt chriſtes righteouſneſſe reputed vnto v owne ¶ may perceaue thinke chriſtes death profiteth v take hys death reſurrection whole redemption ſaluation concernyng men prayer good dedes help one men good déedes prayer ſay profite neighbour yea good woorkes ordeined entent ſhould profite neighbour prayer ought bee made god euery ſtate ſhould graūt ſuch workes prayer ſhould helpe departed thē ſhould ſpeake cleane without booke word god knoweth ſuch thyng let therefore pray dead examine ſelues well fayth fayth leaneth onely word god ſo worde good fayth prayer procede fayth ſurely pleaſe god hebrues xj ſuppoſe ſayth purgatorye could wiſe proued scripture ſome wold yet ſay plainly one ſome would ſay playnly nay let v ſee whether ſorte theſe twayne myght take moſt harme parte wrong firſt beleued purgatory prayer good workes wrought frendes ſoules might relieue therein becauſe vſed much prayer almoſe could leſe reward good wil although opiniō vntrue purgatory ſide beleueth none therfore prayeth none opiniō falſe purgatory deede hee leſeth much good getteth hym alſo much harme hee feareth much leſſe ſinne lye lōg purgatory ſauing hereſie ſhall keepe hym thence ſende hym downe deepe hell aūſwere ſhould take moſt frith harme beleued purgatory opiniō wrong could proued scripture ſuppoſed ſhould ſinne tranſgreſſe agaynſt law god ſayth deut xij commaunde thée onely vnto lord neither adde thyng diminiſh iiij chap ſame booke ye ſhall adde vnto woorde ſpeake vnto neither ſhall ye take thyng agayne v chapter ye ſhall decline neither left hād doyng good owne ſight neither yet vnto right hand doyng manifeſtly forbyd though ſhould ſay doe onely whiche commaunde thée ſayth hee leſe rewarde hys good although opinion vntrue aunſwere yes choſen holyneſſe paule condē neth colloſ 2 ſurely ſhall rather imputed vnto hym ſynne good worke becauſe better beleue ſcripture aloweth thē make fayth ſhould ſayd done fayth ſay vtterly reproued god ſide beleueth ſith proued scripture cā catch harme although opinion falſe rather much good prayſe god good men becauſe feareth ſwerue frō word god leuer leue thyng true caſe purgatory ſet forth scripture ſo ſhall ſure ſinne beleue article yt fayth thyng falſe déede ſo ſhould ſurely ſinne tranſgreſſe agaynſt god holy woorde ſo great perill beleue thyng article fayth whiche opened ſpoken scripture beleue although true yet ryght law condemne may ſée beleue article fayth purgatory ſith proued scripture may condemne man make hym lye euer paynes hell ſhoulde litle lenger lye paynes purgatory one ſo ſhal ſure catch moſt harme beleueth purgatory sauyng ſayth maſter hys hereſie ſhall keepe hym thence ſende downe depe hell ſuppoſed yt could frith proued ſcripture ſtanding ſame ſuppoſitiō calleth hereſie anhereſie ſtiffe holdē opinion repugnant vnto scripture hereſie purgatory bee proued scripture maketh ſuppoſition cā contrary opiniō repugnaunt scripture thus ſuppoſitiō doth euill cal hereſie ſayth ſore iudge opiniō ſhall ſende hym déepe hell verely ſteppeth farre god iudgement conclude determine ſo cruelly ſpecially ſame argument ſuppoſeth proued bee proued scripture whereby ye condemne hym ſo déepe holdeth contrary forſooth fierce iudge god geue eye ſée finallye ye pitie man payne neuer knewe ye payne comparable whoſe fire paſſeth fire purgatory meruellous hot fire farre heate fire euer burned vppon earth hoteſt thoſe paſſeth fayned fire paynted wall verely among poetrie frith reaſon graunt hym yea fire water compariſon enſure hath alone melted gold beholde force fire purgatory ſiluer ſpiritualties profite poore men purſes gold ſmithes fire within england neither yet therewith ragyng heate aſwaged melteth caſtels harde ſtones landes tenementes innumerable ſectes religion monkes frier chanons nunnes prieſtes regulare ſeculare fire multiplication alcumye haue obtayned whole rich pleaſures euen ſwete england ſo muſt graunt hym fire hote may wel perceaue ſlender foūdation hote purgatory hath confutatiō may eaſely ſée hath grounde authority scripture notwithſtandyng foundation religion cloyſters yea goodes nowe theſe ſpiritualtie witty worke men whiche buylde ſo much ſo ſlender foundation howbeit haue made ſo toppeheuye ſurely lyke haue fall thus hath fully aunſwered ſay purgatory maſter full aunſwere hys scripture whiche farre wreſted theyr place alſo hys owne apparent reaſons howbeit hys maſterſhyppe fully pacified let hym groundly open hys mynde bryng purpoſe thinketh make ſhall god grace ſhortly make hym aunſwere quyet mynde ¶ thus endeth ſecond booke ¶ third booke aunſwereth vnto lord rocheſter declareth mynde old doctours addreſſe thirde part ſhallbe aunſwere vnto lord rocheſter reaſons argumentes scripture doctoures diſſouled ſeconde part wyll clene confute god grace thirde booke howbeit chéefeſt byſhop rocheſters diſciple ſcriptures hath peruſed hath maner nothing writtē lord rocheſter ſauing maketh ſelye ſoules pull helpe matter withall lord rocheſter rocheſter firſt patrone purgatory firſt patrone defender thys phantaſie euē tooke worke lord rocheſters euen ſo plucked raſtell hys booke more lord rocheſter confirme hys ſentence rekoneth vp doctor heape iohn william thomas omnes concerning doctor ſo fully hys ſide woulde make thē ſéeme ſone proued ſhould better begin confute hys owne wordes writeth himſelfe vpon xviij article maner man day rocheſter doubteth purgatorye ſayeth yet among olde auncient father eyther none byſhop rocheſters owne wordes el ſeldome mention made alſo among grecian euen vnto day purgatory beleued let read commentary olde grecian ſuppoſe ſhal finde eyther worde ſpoken el theſe lordes wordes wonder obliuiouſnes come vppon hym ſo cleaueth vnto doctor whome affirmed frith eyther make mention el ſeldome notwythſtanding declare ſomewhat doctor may better know theyr meaning ſpeake doctor theyr minde thys matter neceſſarye declare time condition worlde theyr dayes auſtine ambroſe hierome one time euen iiij hundred yeares chriſt yet theyr time ariſen infinite heretikes whole ſectes arrians sectes heretickes domitian eunomians ʋigilanttians pelagians infinite ſo ſwerued truth wreſted scripture frame poſſible one man one man age reſtore agayne vnto true ſenſe among theſe ſome onely fayned purgatory alſo doted ſo far affirmed euery man neuer ſo vicious ſhould ſaued fire aleaged place paul 1 corinthian 3 theſe holy doctours 1 cor 3 perceauing thoſe greate erroures thought beſt condemne thinges indifferētly ſuffer diſſemble wyth leſſe might wéede opinion moſt noyſom apoſtles graunted vnto iewes gentile ſhould kéepe ſome moyſes law actes xv actes 15 might better com purpoſe ſaue iewes gentile firſt vtterly ſet law would iewes neuer haue geuen audience vnto apoſtles euen ſo auſten auſten went wiſely worke firſt condemning scripture errour moſt noyſome wrote thys maner albeit ſome might purged fire yet ſuch apoſtle condemneth ſayeth perſons ſo ſhal poſſeſſe kingdome heauen woulde haue ſtucke vnto paules text 1 cor 3 affirme ſhoulde ſaued thorough fire auſten anſwered paules texte vnderſtande ſpirituall fire temptation affliction tribulation c thys wrote 67 68 hys enchiridion ſubuert groſſe errour ſhould ſaued yt fire purgatory yet 69 goeth litle neare ſayth may doubted whether ſuch purgatory durſt yet openly cōdemne becauſe thought men could time beare booke entituled de vanitate huius ſoeculi doth fully ſhew minde theſe wordes scitote quòd cum anima corpore auſten ſheweth hee thought purgatory auellitur ſtatim aut pro meritis bonis paradiſo collocatur aut pro merit mali inferni tartara praecipitatur wote ye well ſoule departed body eyther put paradiſe according hys good deſertes el thruſt hedlong hell hys ſinnes cleane condemneth purgatory thys done aſſoone ſoule departed body purgatory ſo maketh auſten wholy v thinke ye auſten diſſenteth companion hierome hys owne maſter ambroſe saint ambroſe nay verely howbeit alleage theyr owne wordes iudge saint ambroſe diſſenteth auſtine doth ſtablyſh hys ſentence fully poſſible writeth ſecond chapter hys booke called de bono mortis maner bringing word dauid pſal 39 aduena ego ſum terra peregrinus ſicut omnes patres ambroſe ſheweth opiniō purgatory mei et ideo tanquam peregrinus ad illā ſanctorum communem omnium patriam feſtinabat petens pro huius commorationis inquinamento remitti ſibi peccata priuſquam diſcederet de vita qui enim hîc non acceperit remiſſionem peccatorum illic non erit non erit autem quia ad vitam aeternam non potuerit peruenire quia vita aeterna remiſſio peccatorum eſt ideo que dicit remitte mihi vt refrigerer priuſquam abeam c ſtraunger pilgrime earth father haue bene therfore pilgrime haſted vnto common countrey ſaintes requiring filthines receaued bodely manſion ſinnes might forgeuen departed thys lyfe hath receaued forgeueneſſe hys ſinnes ſhall ſhall ſurely come vnto euerlaſting life euerlaſting lyfe forgeuenes ſinnes therfore ſayth forgeue may cooled depart may euidently perceaue ambroſe knew purgatory forgeueneſſe ſhould thys lyfe plainly affirmeth yt receaueth forgeueneſſe hys ſinnes thys life ſhall neuer come heauen vehement affirmation dubleth hys wordes ſaying hath receyued forgeueneſſe hys ſinnes ſhall ſhall ſurely meaneth ſhall neuer come heauen hath remiſſion saint hieromes minde may ſone saint hierome eccle 9 gathered hys expoſition ix chapter eccleſiaſtes vpon thys text dead haue part thys world worke done vnder sunne addeth ſuffrages prayer good dedes done dead vayne sainte hierome dead adde nothing vnto haue taken life neither good ſinne neyther encreaſe vertue vice albeit ſayth ſome wyll contrarie thys expoſition affirming alſo may encreaſe decreaſe death thrée thing noted firſt text ſayth dead partaker work 1 done vnder ſunne may ſée ſuffrages offringes diriges dead vaine profite partaker nothing vnder ſunne secondarily may ſée hieromes 2 minde dead neyther good euill neyther encreaſe dead neither good euil increaſe vertue vertue vice ſo purgatory put good ſhould purgatory agayne encreaſe vertue lyke lye long purgatorye peraduenture ſome man would thinke good onely ſuffer good aunſwer ſuffereth good doth good man ſhould ſuffer hys body burnt fayth chriſt would ſay good déed yet doth ſuffer thirdly ye may note hierome 3 ignorant certeine fayne purgatory would denye hys expoſition ſay might encreaſe decreaſe vertue vyce death yet notwithſtanding held ſentence condemning theyr opinion whych thing would haue done ſpecially ſith knew ſhould haue aduerſaries except bene ſure ſentence right sée pray onely ſcripture euen theyr owne doctoures condemne phantaſticall purgatory yet lord aſhamed ſay make neuertheleſſe wyll go wyth hym caſe doctours dyd affirme purgatory lord ſayinges doctor farther credited agree yt ſcripture nearer hys purpoſe ʋerely one iote authoritie doctor lordes owne confeſſion extendeth onely admitted whileſt confirme theyr wordes scripture el ſome probable reaſon lorde writeth maner article xxxvij pope hath ſo allowed rocheſter whole doctrine thomas men ſhould beleue euery poynte wrote true neither hath church ſo approued eyther auſtine hierome author doctrine ſome place may diſſent doctor haue erred many thinges many place haue openly declared themſelues men many time haue erred theſe lordes owne word ſith doctours ſomtime erre certayne place admitted graunteth himſelfe ſhould know whē approue deny ſhould hang doctoures authority ſhould well alow vntruth truth ſith affirmeth therfore muſt haue iudge diſcerne betwéene truth falſehode ſhoulde pope nay verely man well doctours may erre ſo ſhall euer vncertaine iudge therefore muſt parciall flexible ignoraunt ſo naturall men excluded muſt inalterable euen ſearching bottome ground thing muſt ʋerely worde god touchſtone tryeth doctrine ſcripture woord god geuen sonne confirmed ſealed holy ghoſt teſtified miracle bloud martyres word iudge muſt examine matter perfit touchſtone tryeth al thing day diſcloſeth iuggeling miſtes doctours ſay thing diſſonant woord admitted holdē truth theyr doctrine diſcorde abhorred holden accurſſed full well agréeth auſten auſtine whiche writeth vnto hierome wiſe deare brother thinke wil haue bookes reputed lyke vnto woorkes prophetes apoſtles scripture reſerued read men workes maner auſten read old auctors would alſo haue mē read workes doe beleue becauſe author ſo ſayth neuer ſo well learned holy except certifie scripture cleare reaſon ſayth true euen ſo would men ſhould read bookes read theſe auſtēs wordes thus haue proued auſten alſo lordes owne wordes man bound beleue doctor except proued true either scripture good reaſon repugnaunt scripture therefore let v ſée scripture good reaſon lord bryngeth approue doctours withall el helpe hym haue declared auſten lordes owne confeſſion although made hym firſt bringeth ſinne agaynſt holy ghoſt math 12 paule 1 cor 3 1 iohn 5 apoca 5 textes paſſe ouer becauſe haue aunſwered vnto ſeconde booke agaynſt firſt reaſon lord hath ſoluted ſayd reaſons already diſſolued ouerhyp groundeth diuers scripture ſoules departed ſome ready damned rocheſter luc 16 hell ſome ready heauen proue true alledgeth parable rich mā luke xv ſure lord ſo ignoraūt ſay parable proueth thyng right vſe parable expound harde texte parable yt ſcripture proue nothing open expound dark hard thinges poynte touched could entre euery man capacitie neither thynges lyke ſpoken ſimilitude neither yet thynges true touched parable muſt conſider thyng wherefore ſpokē apply onely ſpoken let reſidue go william tyndall hath well declared vnto parable wicked mammon parable hard expounded cauſe man wel eſpye text purpoſe ſpoken ſhould ſéeme cauſe many phariſeis multitude would beleue preaching chriſt although confirmed wordes authoritie moſes prophetes curious ſome deale phantaſticall therfore would beleue woordes except ſome apparition bene made vnto thē might haue bene aſſured dead hys wordes true vnto ſuch lyke hee ſpeaketh parable playnly concludyng ſhould haue ſuch apparition dead alſo neceſſary moſes moſes prophetes meant old teſtament prophetes would geue credence ſhould beleue although one dead ſhould ryſe againe tell notwithſtandyng let graunt hym ſome ready hell ſome heauen thyng ſhall neuer bee able proue scripture yea playnly deſtroyeth reſurrection taketh awaye argumentes wherewith chriſt paule doe proue ſhall ryſe yet ſay let graunt hym ſée cōclude foloweth neither credible ſayth rocheſter whiche caſt hell ſhould ſtreight way goe heauen therfore muſt put purgatorye may purged aunſwere liue faythfull frith vnfaythfull vnfaythfull ii place life heauen hell damned iohn 3 beleue condemned gone death lyfe iohn 3 5 righteous man hee dyeth ſhall reſt peace sapi 3 euery faithful mā righteous god yt whole epiſtle romaine proueth ergo euery faythfull man ſhall reſt peace tormented paynes purgatory touchyng poynte reſt dare bold ſay hand god god would ſhould ignoraunt take vpon v determine matter peraduenture would enquire ſith parable ſayth lazarus abraham boſome ſignifieth reſted abraham boſome abraham boſome would aūſwere abraham boſome nothyng el abraham fayth called child abraham becauſe hys perfite fayth whiche ought folow fayth many maner infinite degrées notwithſtandyng greater thē muſtard ſéede ſay ſmall yet ſhal ſaue v departeth fayth reſteth peace wayteth laſt day god ſhall geue vnto hys faythfull elect onely elect faythfull faythfull elect crowne glorie elect faithful faythful elect hath prepared loue hym crowne doth paule ſay ſhall receaue day 2 timo 4 day iudgement meane ſeaſon god hath ſo prouided v ſhall wayte vntill number brother dayly ſuffer ſhall ſuffer chriſt wholy fulfilled ſo ſhall made perfite without v hebr xj lord vnderſtād abraham boſome heauen contentious let chriſten iudge ſentence ſemeth moſt true abraham boſome proue purgatory cleare caſe cā proue purgatory vnfaythfull ready dāned faythfull reſt peace let call wil whether reſt heauen reſt fayth vntill laſt day ſure man ſo madde reſt peace lye tormentes ſay reſt peace ſhould ſignifie lye paynes purgatory furthermore text ſhal rather make ſore agaynſt hym thē thyng hym lazarus while hée lyuyng without ſinne man el 1 iohn 1 ſo 1 iohn 1 man long hath breath hys body ſay without ſinne ſhould hee make iohn lyar yet lazarus caried purgatory purged ſinnes remainyng body houre death wherefore good concluſion againſt purgatory may conclude ſuch purgatory god iuſt vnto hym vnto v therefore would purge hym well v agayne mercyfull vnto v vnto wel forgeue v hym without broyling yt coales purgatory iuſtice mercye euer one alterable perfite purgatiō pure bloud chriſt waſheth away ſinne world albeit euer haue remnauntes dregges chriſtes death hath ouercom •• death turned life ſinne rebellion mē bers long haue lyfe yet wholy finiſhed death ſuch efficacitie chriſtes death hath turned death hys faythfull layed vpon v payne ſinne medicine agaynſt ſinne fully cureth maketh end well figured golias ſlaine hys owne ſword lord bryngeth rocheſter math 12 purpoſe math xij mē ſhal geue accoumptes euery idle worde haue ſoluted agaynſt frith thinke ſhal ſay hym ſelfe aunſwered men ſhall geue rekonyng day dome text ſayth ſhould rather argue purgatory wherein thoſe ſinnes ſhould purged bene purged ſhoulde geue accoumpte proued purgatory muſt domeſday none thyng ſhould proue purgatory domeſday man euer ſo fooliſh graunt true vnderſtādyng text two kyndes men one faythfull vnfaythfull faythful fayth chriſtes bloud ready fully faythfull purged hart rebellious mēbers death wholly ſubdued theſe men ſhall geue reckoning neyther idle woorde euill déed theyr ſinnes couered chriſt hys bloud ſhall geue whole accomptes vnfaythfull theyr vtter confuſion ſhall haue booke theyr conſcience vnfaythfull opened ſhall preſented theyr euill deades woordes thoughtes theſe chriſt ſpeaketh ſhall geue thys great accompt note alſo text called men woord scripture men euer moſt part taken worſte ſenſe ſignifieth wicked men fleſhly men men folow luſtes appetite confirmeth purgatory 66 pſalme ſayth rocheſter pſal 66 haue gone fire water thou haſt brought v coleneſſe ſure haue forgotten alledgeth frith zacharie 9 prophet zachary ix affirmeth th • water purgatory hard make theſe rocheſter agree two agrée mē ground lye moſt part theyr tale probation cōtrary well ſtand together neuertheleſſe one poynte agrée full well ſay vntruly neither nother text ſerueth whit purgatory concernyng place zachary ſufficiētly declared meaneth wil alſo declare vnder ſtandyng text firſt ſerue purgatory beſech haue pſalter read pſalme thinke ſhal wonder • yng dreames ignoraunce allege text purgatory text ye pſalme true interpretatiō 66 pſalme thou haſt brought v ſtraite laden backes trouble heuyneſſe thou haſt ſet men vpon heades haue gone fire water thou haſt led v agayn place refreſhyng textes ſame pſalme ſuffer place ſhould vnderſtand purgatory text immediately ſayth thou haſt ſet men vpon heades chiefeſt defender purgatory euē hym ſelfe ſay men deuils torment ſoules purgatory notwithſtandyng lord rocheſter rocheſter cānot agree good man affirmeth aungels whiche torment ſoules neuer man doted ſo farre ſay men torment ſoules purgatory wherefore may conclude text ment purgatory prophet mēt men ranne ouer childrē iſraell ſubdued wrapped thē extreme trouble scripture ſignified fire water beſides textes folowyng wil admit ſhould vnderſtād purgatory foloweth immediatly enter thy houſe • urt offrynges ſhall offer vnto thée fat ſacrifices reke wether ſhall burne ox goates mā ſo mad thinke ſoules purgatory soules purgatory cānot offer ox goates ſacrifice ſhould offer vnto god ſuch ſacrifices text playnly vnderſtand child iſraell lord deliuered afflictiōs enemy offred theyr loyall ſacrifices prayſe thankes lord theyr ſhield protection nowe flyeth lorde vnto church ſayth becauſe rocheſter churche hath affirmed muſt needes beleue church cā erre touchyng poynte frith referre vnto woorke william tyndal hath writtē agaynſt wherin ye ſhal wel perceiue church chriſt chirch ſayth rocheſter meaning pope church erre hys churche neuer determined ſuch thyng sinagoge sathan maketh article fayth bindeth mēs conſciēces scripture waxeth lordſhyp ſomewhat hote agaynſt martine luther becauſe would man ſhould compelled beleue purgatory lord ſayth profitable wel done compel men beleue ſuch thynges whether ſtabliſhe opinion hée plucketh word parable luke xiiij luke 14 certayne man made great ſupper ſayd vnto ſeruaūtes go forth quickly wayes compell enter verely chriſt ment frith thyng apoſtles ſhould go forth world preach parable luke 14 truly interpreted word vnto nation openyng vnto miſerable ſtate conditiō agayne mercy god hath ſhewed thē ſonne chriſt would chriſt apoſtles ſhould expound lay ſo euidently reaſons scripture miracle vnto gentils ſhould euē manifeſt perſuaſions compelled graunt vnto chriſt take vpon fayth chriſt maner chriſt compel men ſhould compelled beleue saduces graunt reſurrection math xxij theſe meanes compelled hee phariſeis graunt theyr conſciences dyd miracle power god yet afterward hate knowyng theyr harte contrary ſayd ye dyd power deuill math xij ſay chriſt chriſt meeke gentle tyrannous ſchole maſter would haue diſciples compell men priſonment fetter ſcourgyng ſword fire falſe farre mildeneſſe chriſtē ſpirite although lord approue neuer ſo much chriſt dyd forbyd diſciples ſuch tyrāny yea rebuked becauſe would haue deſired fire ſhould deſcende heauen conſume samaritanes wold receiue chriſt luke ix commaunded luke 9 mē would receiue doctrine ſhould departe thence ſpryncle duſt féete teſtimony agaynſt vnfaythfull bene preached vnto word life violence god haue man compelled vnto law paule alſo teſtifieth 2 cor 1 rule ouer paul ſayth power ouer fayth corinthiās touchyng theyr fayth fayth ſtand lord infidelitie fall hym man ſearch hart onely god ſo man iudge order fayth onely god thorough holy ſpirite furthermore fayth gifte god diſtributeth hys owne pleaſure 1 cor 12 geue 1 cor 12 day may geue morow thou perceaue exterior worke thy neighbour haue enſtruct god word pray god geue hym grace beleue rather poynte chriſten man compell man death exterior violence finally doth thy compulſion fayth procured violence mere onely gift god violence ʋerely nothing make ſtarke hypocrits man compel hart beleue thing except ſée euidence ſufficiente profe haue herd tell boy preſent hys father burning hys beléefe aſſone officer eſpyed boy ſayd ech let v take hym examine alſo peraduenture ſhal finde great heretike hys father boy ſaw hys father dead catchpoles began ſnatch ſore diſmayed thought ſhould dye one appoſed aſking beleeued aunſwered maſter beleue euen pleaſeth euen ſo tormentes crafty handling man may compelled ſay beleueth thing neyther thinketh yet beleue feare maketh fayth fayth mās fayth power doth god accepte thys thing ſay beleue indéede beleue ʋerely vtterly condemneth whether opinion true falſe opinion true example fayth chriſtes bloud iuſtifieth god confeſſe byſhops england mouth beleue wyth mine hart nothing better ſhould haue part chriſtes bloud much worſe firſt god condemneth iudgeth myne hart alſo mine owne hart condemneth becauſe haue openly graunted mine hart denyeth contrariwyſe ſhould beleue thys fully mine hart yet fayth firſt gift god procedeth hart may compelled feare perſecution ſhould deny examined openly fayth ſhall condemned god except repent alſo myne owne hart ſhall witnes condemne ſo noiſome vngodly compelled vnto thing god euer ſearcheth hart compelled bvt lord obiecteth writing vppon rocheſter xviij article ſaying man take away purgatorye entent ſhall need pardon long ſayth man regarded purgatory man ſought pardon eſtimation pardon hangeth pardon thereof ſo ſhall haue rocheſter ſayth herein truly yet ware neede purgatorye verely care though graūt thinke mouy mother ſcripture ſhall able proue neyther nother mammon great god euē power enough innent ſuch knackes yea make article fayth burne thoſe purgatory pardōs haue bene goodly marchaundiſe clergye beleue preaty practiſe make ſuch pointes article fayth holy father geuen vp preaching would take paynes neyther ſerue theyr brother ſette vp ſuch article fayth ſhoulde bring money vpholde theyr eſtate withall would beleue rid way feare diſcloſing theyr iugling doubteth pardon purgatory plucketh holye father bearde notwithſtanding lord confirmeth rocheſter pardon purgatory text chriſt ſpake vnto peter math 16 geue kayes kingdome heauen whatſoeuer thou bindeſt vpon earth ſhall bound heauen whatſoeuer thou loſeſt earth ſhall loſed heauen theſe woordes ſayth lord bene ſpoken vayne could geue pardon loſe men purgatory c touching kayes albeit frith haue oftentimes bene declared maner euery treatiſe hath bene put forth engliſh tongue yet ſomewhat ſhew minde one kaye heauen chriſt calleth kaye knowledge luc 11 kay kayes luke 11 worde god chriſt rebuked law geuers taking away thys kay knowledge word god kay people wyth theyr tradition falſe expoſitions fully excluded kaye knowledge word god cleane ſhut vp scripture haue done nowe dayes alſo called kaye dauid whych ſhutteth man openeth openeth apoc 3 man ſhutteth apoc 3 becauſe theſe two effectes worketh ſhutteth openeth hath nomination kayes yet ſayd indéede one worde god thys kay kayes call wyll ſith know meaneth chriſt deliuered vnto peter vnto hys apoſtles like ſhall eaſely perceaue marke geuen mat 16 math 16 onely promiſed yet geuen chriſt ſayd geue thée kayes geue thée riſen death performed hys promiſe gaue kayes indifferentlye thou mayſt ſée ioh 20 luke cap 24 iohn 20 luke 24 chriſt gaue kayes peter reſt apoſtles expoundeth opened theyr wittes vnderſtand scripture repentaunce forgeueneſſe might preached c therfore woord bindeth loſeth thorough preaching thou telleſt theyr vice iniquity condemning thē law bindeſt thou woorde god thou preacheſt mercy chriſt vnto repent open ſhut binde loſe dooſt thou looſe word god therfore preacheth woorde god neyther binde loſe though call ſelfe pope contrarywiſe preacheth worde bindeth looſeth well peter paule although called sir iohn countrey conſequently ſay pope cā deliuer ſoule purgatory one vaine lie except proue goeth downe vnto pope deliuer ſoule purgatory except firſt go thether preach vnto preacheth vnto woorde god ſalt muſt ſeaſon kay muſt let looſing none likewiſe ſay pope geue pardon redéeme ſinnes except preach chriſtes bloud hath pardoned euen like vanitie thinketh alſo wadeth déepe deſcende purgatorye thys text text ſaith ſoeuer bindeth earth ſhall math 16 bound heauen whatſoeuer looſeth earth c graunt themſelues purgatory purgatory earth rocheſter ſayth third place hel earth thirde place hell therfore paſſeth bondes ſtretch hand purgatory ſo text ſerue notwithſtanding lorde content geue thys power onely hath ſo farre waded pope power hath graunted full auctoritie deliuer men hell damned already ſayth whoſoeuer hath committed capitall crime rocheſter hath therby deſerued damnation rocheſter place far beſide himſelfe yet may pope deliuer hym crime alſo frō payne due vnto affirmeth thre time xxj article feare forgetting vpon poynte litle reaſon frith lord ſo wil make end pope may deliuer mā cryme hath committed alſo payne due vnto affirme may ſame authoritie deliuer xx hundred thouſand yea world ſure ſhewe reaſon may deliuer ſome let deliuer playne declaration ye pope tyranny euery man poynte death crime frō payne ſo ſhall neuer man neither enter hell yet purgatory beſt dede moſt charitableſt euer hée dyd yea ought could although ſhould coſt hym owne lyfe ſoule thereto moſes exod 〈◊〉 rom 9 paule geue exāple yet ieoperdy neither cā ſay moſt wretched cruell tyraunt euer lyued euen ſonne perdition woorthy bée damned hundred thouſand helles haue receaued ſuch pope proude ſhameleſſe tyranous antichriſt power god hée may ſaue men yet wil ſuffer ſo many damned report vnto ſelues hée worthy haue man would ſolute reaſon ſay may méete hym becauſe theyr paynes god iuſtice may ſatiſfied ſay euaſion nothyng worth neyther yet cā imagine way wherby may haue apparēce eſcape lord ſayth hym ſelfe pope muſt pacifie god iuſtice euery ſoule hée deliuereth purgatory therefore blaſphemous pope deuils vicar hath imagined pope hath hys hand merites chriſtes paſſiō may apply pleaſure alſo ſayth merites chriſtes paſſion ſufficient redeme ſinnes world ſith theſe merites part ſufficiēt ſatiſfie ye iuſtice god redeme whole world alſo pope hath hand diſtribute pleaſure lacketh euen pope diſtribution vnto ſaluatiō world may pacifie god wrath ſatiſfie hys iuſtice ſayth lord applying theſe merites lacke good workes ſo pope wil god iuſtice may bée fully ſatiſfied whole worlde ſaued hée may ſo iuſtly eaſely ſaue whole world charitie alſo mouyng vnto yet apply theſe merites pope ſonne perdition worthy payne imagined rocheſters doctrine true ſo frutefully faulte onely ſonne perdition worthy payne imagined ſo reaſon improued much ſtabliſhed thinke ineuitable beholde pray whether lord rocheſter hath brought holy father auauncyng hys power ſo high euen yt déepeſt pit hell lord ſayd true impoſſible hym auoyde chaunceth vnto hym euen doth cuſtomably ſuch pryde raigneth whē hygheſt fall downe headlong vnto vtter confuſion ruine man féele himſelfe gréeued yet fully ſatiſfied matter let write hys minde god grace ſhall make hym aunſwere ſpéede pray christen reader woord god may encreaſe amen ¶ booke agaynſt raſtell named ſubſedye bulwarke firſt booke made iohn frithe pryſoner tower neadeth chriſtē reader thinke thou haſt ouerread diligentlye pondered thine inward ſenſes treatiſe iohn frith wherein confuteth reaſon raſtel rocheſter made maintenance vpholding bitter paynes purgatory commende vnto thee thys briefe worke folowing named ſubſedy ſubſedy defence bulwarke defence bulwarke ſame much le nedeth dehorte thee vayne childiſh feare forefather haue place purgatory theyr good woorkes day remayne vppon earth founded theyr thence deliueraunce teſtifie foraſmuch thou art chriſten man reioyſeſt chriſt dare boldlye affirme thee thou takeſt neyther pleaſure ioy place like ſome perſons much ioy made yt finding purgatory although ſmall purpoſe triumphed late much ioy clapping handes ſent tidinges partes purgatorye founde agayne becauſe read booke named inſtitution chriſten man worde purgatory yet haue heard hetherto ſelfe ſame perſons haue ſhewed token gladnes god woorde tranſlated engliſh ſo ſeeme reioyce haue ſely ſoules purged puniſhmentes departed haue purged worde god wil think haue vttered theyr harte concerning purgatory theyr tongue euen ſo ſay theyr ſtomakes holy father pope whome may iuſtly call biſhop rome ſeeing chriſt deuided peter paule head peter church may call head paules church london byſhop london hath recouered agayne england old authority yea neuer yet loſt becauſe finde theyr church cope rope bel beades lyke holineſſe themſelues long gownes ſhauen crownes finger annointed holy oyle idlenes ſay theſe holy reliques declare byſhop rome clarkly worde purgatory proueth place ſoules departure theyr body ſuffer paine puniſhmentes doth preaty pageant purgatory ſignifie prognoſticate tragedye play hereafter word god ſhall blow ſcatter face earth darke cloudes miſtes men inuentions ſhall ſcoure away yt ruſt fleſhly vnderſtanding ſcriptures thing likewiſe hath done ought may found booke wherwith may reſiſt ſuch thinges may picked fruite commonly hath come counſels conuocations ſynodes ſince apoſtles time excepted cauſeth ſomewhat feare mā wey good bad hath ſprong perchaunce thinke lay people eſtates may well iuſtly ſay farewell one wyth maruayll haue bene child one father haue bene counſels haue bene ſheepe haue gone ſheepes clothing oft time greater part ouercommeth better thing gathered experience reading cauſeth oftentimes wiſhe would counted ſinceere true miniſters goſpell eyther might would cleane abſtayne ſuch counſelles haue part el would geue place fruites infidelitie meane man inuentions carnall interpretation fayth chriſt neuer begatte paule gaue peter hys colleague left table gentile went iewes facte peter iudgement paule might conueniently haue approued ſeeing peter entent would offēd weake brother iewes wyth hys eating true ſincere miniſters chriſt goſpell may winke many thinges vſed theſe dayes among diſciples goſpell much leſſe may approue thē faſhion theyr liuing confirme auctoritye counſell preching ſay time ſpeake againſt thē yet time leaue longer ſeeme allow vnleſſe entend alwayes walk author booke looked time ſome written againſt purgatorye feare ſome maintaine blindnes theyr ſimulation open lyght theyr preaching haue ſpoken good reader beſides purpoſe none admoniſh rocheſter raſtel three defender one herely although rocheſter raſtell haue three thou perceiueſt reading thys former treatiſe ſtiffely defended one hereſie yet ſhouldeſt thou haue three one iudgement opinion rocheſter men high dignitie thys worlde one byſhop chauncelor noble realme england auncient yeares ſo great ſophiſticall called naturall reaſon raſtel •… rior rocheſter appartayning god worde acknowledged himſelfe ignoraunt therof notwtſtanding ſuch opinion witte thought could well proue purgatory two done ſcriptures wherin thinke deceiued theſe three perſons like ſo tooke aunſwer made like rocheſter rocheſter thoughte foule •… ne iohn f •• th •• anſwere thought foule ſcorne ſee glory world high eſtimation ſelues doth yong man ſmall reputation ſhoulde take vppon ſo cleane contrary theyr opinion write againſt ſhort tooke matter ſo greuouſlye could neuer quiet theyr ſtomackes vntill dronken bloud raſtell though perceaued naturall reaſon ſore ſayd yet malicious therfore wrote agayne worke raſtell came raſtel malicious gladly recogniſed ignorance handes priſoner tower london made aunſwere following ſame aunſwer raſtel read well content count naturall reaſon fooliſhnes wyth harty thankes geuen god became childe againe ſucked wiſedome commeth aboue ſaueth noriſhed therewith continued liues end honor glory god whome prayſe euer amen ¶ foloweth preface booke brother raſtell thāke hath pleaſed ſo fauourable vnto poore priſoner ſhew copie booke whiche haue written confute reaſons scripture haue alledged agaynſt purgatory hath cauſed make ſubſidie defēce bulwarke booke whiche god grace ſhalbe occaſion open light although yet leſtwiſe vnto whoſe harte prince world hath blinded 2 cor 4 light goſpell glorie chriſt may ſhyne write proteſt bryng scripture agaynſt onely rehearſe scripture agayne haue alledged vnperfeitly woūde myne owne dartes euen one playeth tennes toſſing balle agayne doe verye well admitte ſimilitude notwithſtanding know right well inough man playing tennes toſſe balle agayne iohn frith ſemeth could pla • well ten •… e muſt ſo toſſe take ſmite ouer agayne game great ieoberdy beſides hee muſt take heede neither ſmite ſhort line yet vnder loſſe bene better let goe finally ſometyme man ſmiteth ouer thynketh yet vngracious poſt ſtandeth way maketh ball rebounde backe againe ouer corde ſo loſeth game wil anger man aſſartayne ye haue toſſed neuer ball ye offende one theſe pointes yet beſides ſome tyme ye playe touche legerdemayne caſt ball whē commeth perceaue none mine court ſhall iudge ſame theſe poyntes ſhalbe declared come aunſwere order raſtell prologue aſſigned two cauſes making firſt booke purgatory allegyng textes ſcripture ye profe therof controuerſie two ſortes people one ſorte raſtel alleageth two cauſes made hys fyrſt booke defence purgatorie ſay thoſe beleue chriſt deny chriſt scripture bee turkes paynimes ſuch miſcreauntes ſort beleue chriſt ſcripture wil deny text holy ſcripture yet conſtrue expounde interprete theſe text theyr owne willes obſtinate mynde c let v conſider foreſayd cauſes ponder whether booke haue may ſuch good ſay pretended whether haue conuerted thoſe ſortes people el thyng lykely ſuch fact firſt let v ſée profiteth yt firſt ſort infidel beleuyng chriſt ſcripture ſauiour chriſt ſayth beleueth iohn 3 iohn frith anſwereth raſtels two cauſes damned iohn baptiſt confirmeth ſame ſaying beleueth ye ſonne hath euerlaſtyng lyfe beleueth ſonne ſhal ſée life wrath god abydeth vpon hym euidēt expoſition conſent chriſten men thoſe infidel damned entent ſhould raſtell teach purgatory without chriſt ther way dānation ſcripture faythfull men teſtifie would know way wold perſuade purgatory ſhould away meane ſaluation damnatiō thē beleue chriſt raſtelles firſt cauſe proued vaine ſure thinke raſtell leueth alſo infideles ſhall neuer come though one may ſée firſt cauſe vayne dyd beleue déede deceyued let v procéede vnto ſecond ſort people beleue chriſt ſcripture yet miſconſtrue expoundyng theyr willes let v ſée frute take booke profiteth ſhall finde leſſe ſerueth theſe men firſt men beleue chriſt hys scripture poſſible ſhould receaue admitte thyng agaynſt scripture expoſition ſelues world agaynſt scripture faithfull mē ſhould way health exclude chriſt hys scripture ſith purgatory counted away health would go proue ſecludyng chriſt scripture agaynſt scripture faythfull men beſides ſo obſtinate receaue verye scripture expounde willes wreſt ſame wil much leſſe receaue booke ſo playne agaynſt ſcripture therfore would thinke could bee tamed booke notwithſtandyng ſo wreſteth scripture may wel apt good example lyken hym hath wilde horſe tame perceiueth hee hold hym ſcoktiſhe ſnafle yet labour breake rootē twine threde eſpye maner profite cā come booke alledge better cauſes yet ſhew bene great deale better vnwritten brother raſtel ſay frith aunſwereth gently raſtels bitter tauntes auaunce boaſt ſelfe much becommeth detract ſlaūder neighbour prouoke men read booke rather vyce vertue ſuch thynges ye lay charge truſt ſhall declare inconuenience geue ſufficient aunſwere ¶ aunſwere raſtels firſt chapter reproueth boaſtyng ſelfe firſt chapter booke raſtell raſtell laboureth proue ſore ouer ſéene laudyng boaſtyng ſelfe lyke ſelfe ſo well ſure men lyke leſſe feareth god therfore lyke fauour rather worſe better iuggeleth wyth frith would make beleue toſſed mine ball agayne beholde perceaue none mine hath cut frith meteth falſe ball ſhoulde make ſo hath geuen cleane ſhape euer entended ſhould haue appeareth hys writing rehearſeth word maner ſure many raſtell maruell ſo yong dare attempt diſpute thys matter agaynſt theſe thrée perſons wordes frith theſe ſure many much maruell ſo yong ſo ſmal learning dare diſpute matter c raſtell leaueth wordes ſo ſmall learning put bewrayed himſelfe thincke man ſo mad ſay ſayeth himſelfe yong ſmall learning ſhoulde prayſe boaſte hym ſelfe alſo immediatly wordes note modeſty iohn frith hys firſt allegation ſay thys maner touching lerning muſt needes acknowledge truth ſmall thinke baſe boaſting anone ſay would man ſhould admit wordes learning except ſtand wyth ſcripture approued therby lay touchſtone trye god word found falſe contrary damne alſo ſhall reuoke mine hart c finally exhorted read booke aduertiſing ſpeaketh wordes rather ſpoken wordes might well ſee entended boaſt ſelfe haue written left euē firſt page calleth wherin reporteth boaſt ſelfe notwithſtanding one thing doth raſtell ſore vexe ſhould recite epiſtle paule wherby ſaith would haue men beleue ſpirite god thinke though young ſée viſions eſpye truth myne elder haue dreamed dreames wandered phantaſies thys recounteth great frith boaſt thys one place ſhoulde winne fielde whereunto aunſwer indéede wordes proue thing ſéeme man ought cō demne hath ſene ſo ſurely gather wordes argue maner man ought condemne thing read geue ſentence becauſe ſéeme ignoraunt matter ſhall declare vnto ſtandeth coulour rhetorike called auantopodoſis ſaye aunſwere obiection man might haue made thys maner thou graunteſt thy ſelf yong ſo ſmall learnyng dooſt thou thinke ſhall read regard thy booke ſpecially ſith written againſt auncient mē great wit dignity theſe two pointes aunſwer preuenting theyr obiection ſhould deſpiſe becauſe youth ſpirite god bound place euen ſo addict age perſon enſpyreth bring example god inſpireth youth aſwell age enſpyred yong timothy prouing thereby youth ſelfe deſpiſed according learning bringeth therfore may deſpiſe youth firſt read doctrine bring therafter iudge proue enſpyred haue ſpirite god timothie onely proue god may enſpyre youth tymothe therefore ye ought firſt read condemne know enſpyred vntill haue read theyr workes ſéene theyr factes thus may ſée wordes define youth enſpired although ſome may exhort 〈◊〉 theſſ 1 man deſpiſe propheſies proue approue good make matter playne ſhall bring example paule hebrues hebr 13 exhorteth hoſpitalitie ſome men vnwares haue receaued angel harbour therefore vnmindfull paule exhorteth hoſpitalitie ſhewing thoſe meanes ſome men haue receaued angel houſe would haue thinke yt geſtes ſhall receaue ſhall angel ſome ſhall leud loſels likewiſe exhorting read booke deſpiſing youth becauſe ſometime god enſpireth yong would haue thinke bookes made yong men ye ſhall receaue ſhall holeſome doctrine ſome men lewd vnfruitfull neuertheleſſe euen receaued thoſe geſts ſhould alſo put away angel came deſpiſe read ſuch bookes written young men may alſo fortune deſpiſe written inſpiration chriſtes ſpirit therefore ye ought read caſe indéed praiſed frith ſpeaketh cauillers ſelfe haue ſayd spirite god inconuenience ſhould folow thereof would therof argue doctrine falſe good argument chriſtes doctrine falſe paule falſe prophet fayth nothing chriſt ſaid iewes iohn 8 light worlde againe ſayd father glorified whome ye call god bene carnall eye ſayth thincketh ſelfe inferiour vnto yt hyeſt apoſtles ſayth againe glory miniſters chriſt though ſpeake vnwiſely copious labour ſtripes aboue meaſure priſon often often poynt death c theſe word thinke doctrine right nayverely doth improue doctrine may good holeſome man may boaſt ſelfe well ſo referre yt prayſe god goodnes commeth caſe ſhould ſay god hys mere mercy loue oweth chriſt hys bloud geuen hys ſpirite thankfull godly boaſting might laude prayſe thankes euer amen would thinke ſo greate boaſtyng doctrine ſhould impayred therby ah blinde guide pray god geue light vnderſtandyng beſeche brother raſtell diſcōtent aſke one queſtion ye chriſten man ſure aunſwere yes brought text paule ſayth hath yt ſpirite god none rom 8 pray auoyde notwithſtādyng wold auoyde yt text yet lay blocke way ſhal able remoue ſaying paule 2 corin 13 know ye 2 cor 13 ſelues chriſt except ye reprobate perſons ſoeuer would iudge ſelues thinke verely ſuch therfore whereas dyd ſo write certifie frith faithful ſeruaunt true martyr chriſt chriſtes cōclude ye wil day ſhall come ſhall ſurely know ſo albeit meane ſeaſon reputed laughyng ſtoke world know truſt deceaue bryngeth againſt raſtell ſay haue bene long ſecluded frō scripture alſo fore father haue yt light god word opened vnto maruell raſtell meaneth frith bryngyng purpoſe raſtell ſheweth himſelf ignoraunt thinke boaſtyng ſelfe ye thinke vntrue thinke blynde scripture hath poore common bene admitted vnto euen til day hath bene hid locked vp ſtraunge tounge haue attayned knowledge toung hath bene locked thouſand falſe gloſes antichriſtes makyng innumerable lawes ſay forefather haue frith ſheweth meaning yt ſcripture kept forefather light god worde opened vnto meane haue scripture owne mother toung might haue conferred theſe iugglyng miſtes light god word proceſſe wordes teſtifie hath holy left beſech chriſtē reader read place diſcharge confuſion ye ſhall finde ſecōd leafe booke alledgeth agaynſt ſhould ſay iudge chriſten raſtell reader reaſons raſtell hath brought hath ſoluted thē minde reaſons ſolutions ſo childiſh vnſauery ſo vnlearned baren ſo full faultes phantaſies rather pitie man déepe ignoraunce blyndnes hath ſo deceiued ſelfe philoſophie naturall reaſon feare vayne probation ſhould allure man conſent vnto hym thinke raſtell layeth agaynſt frith becauſe boaſt ſelfe theſe wordes verely touchyng truth thoſe woordes adde thus much vnto thē neuer wyſt man yt coūted wiſe whiche hath brought ſo ſlender reaſons except entended deſtroy thing ye ſéeme haue build finally exhorte men iudge conferre scripture raſtell syr thomas lorde rocheſter alleadge theyr opinion would haue ponder reaſons raſtell cauileth ſolutions vnto annexyng theſe wordes ſure yt ſmal learning hath condēned hygh eloquence folye hath brought nought wiſedome youth hath diſcloſed feſtered ignoraunce raſtell thinketh ſtād frith well owne conceite boaſt ſelfe aboue moone becauſe touch kynſman let raſtell take aunſwere would kéepe within owne bondes medling would ignorant thing therfore vnderſtood nothing ſhould haue vnderſtand neyther duty prince yet god worldly matter onely would neuer compare yet muſt remember dawber may correct hym owne craft euen socrates ſayeth man wiſe one thyng hée take vpon define thynges ignoraunt nothyng ſo diſdayneth gift hath proueth hym ſelfe vnwiſe furthermore ſée great praiſe attribute vnto ſelfe confeſſe ſmall learning folly youth neuertheleſſe recount prayſe becauſe ſay hath cōdemned theyr hie eloquence theyr wiſedome diſcloſed theyr ignoraunce let hym alſo annexe wordes wrote ſaying euen olde practiſe god chooſe fooliſh thing worlde confound wiſe chooſe weak confound mighty good concluſiō made iohn frith againſt raſtels firſt chapter chooſe vile thing reputation confound thē hye degrée fleſh might boſt ſelfe ſight onely prayſe thankes euer amen men may ſée referre prayſe onely worthy ſo may conclude haue looked indifferently booke aunſwer vnto raſtels ſecond chapter improueth rayling diſpraiſing others ſecond chapter raungeth raſtell field ſearcheth diligence worde haue ſpoken might takē worſt ſence calleth rayling geſting ſcolding woordes becauſe would haue abhorred reader alleageth onely theſe wordes ſpoken againſt himſelfe alſo ſpoken againſt lorde rocheſter ſyr thomas entendeth aunſwer defend theyr party ye may ſure onely leaue nothing behinde ſhould ſéeme make like noble orator wordes reproueth theſe raſtell taketh hys foundation raſtell vpon ſtarke lye maketh two lye maketh thrée lye would deſire brother frith raſtell pardon little ignoraunce ſurely thought bene offence call lye lye call ſhéepe ſhéepe notwithſtanding ſith recounteth rayling geſting ſcolding hereafter temper ſelfe chaunge word ſay lyeth hys leaue maketh fitten angreth ſay raſtell raſtel hath loſt wit purgatory therefore ſay ſo frith thys affirme raſtell neuer ſo furious whoſoeuer maketh ſuch reaſons ſolutions counteth good earneſt hath wit hys head whereſoeuer loſt would read raſtels firſt argument haue ſet booke twelf leafe ſhall perceyue whether ſay truth alſo aleageth ſhould ſay raſtell ſaying raſtell againſt ſcripture ye count railing would haue ſay ſo much vnto count man ſomwhat frith ſtately enſure god ſuffer liue wyll ſay ſo agayne take alſo reciteth great reproch raſtell ſhould ſay marueyll ſcholemen may abide felow ſurely ſame ſay agayne frith proueth ſainte thomas alſo foles double f • oles ſhoulde ſo would counted baynous hereſie rehearſeth ſay raſtell l rocheſter helpe matter ſay ſmall probation ſlender reaſons thoſe two witted men syr thomas lorde rocheſter brought confirme purgatorye made hart yerne rayling ieſting let frith men iudge thys dare auow ſayd truth ſhould man ſay ſée ſo contrary theyr tale ſayeth rocheſter contrary contrary rocheſter fire water purgatory lord rocheſter ſayth fire water ſayth miniſters puniſhment deuils lorde rocheſter ſayth miniſters puniſhment angel ſayth grace charity lye paynes purgatory increaſed lorde rocheſter ſayth ſoules purgatory obtayne neyther fayth grace charitie thē brought iudge good reader whether haue rayled ſayde trueth doth raſtell leaue full craftely reciteth full diligently head tayle middle expoundeth matter wil let ſée alleageth alſo againſt raſtell ſay ſore deceaued ſet ſand euen firſt brunt beginning hys voyage would wiſh little witte euen ſay agayne affirme frith true ſo euidently proued beginning mine aunſwer agaynſt néed ſay nothing referre reader vnto place alſo improueth ſaying raſtell place ſheweth one text twiſe ignoraunt yt buſte vnderſtandeth phraſe ſcripture ſuch ſayinges frith alleageth paſſe ouer count folly ſpend paper laboure rehearſing read booke ſhall ſée theſe point ſo plainly proued mought aſhamed make mention counteth geſting ſlaundering raſtell rayling ſaying reaſonable man thincke theſe poyntes thinges belonging vertue rather ſpices braunches raſtell bitter taunter pride ſhew ſelf therin charitable rather malicious wiſedome therein rather • olly adding bene halfe yeare two ſcholes ſay ſchole diſcretion ſchole charitie ſhould haue proſpered vertuous learning haue done ſcholes vij yeare ſayth haue bene ſcholes ſlaundering rayling geſting deare brother bene ſo frith ſpoken certayne wordes déede mighte haue ſéemed eye rayling detracting ſlaundring haue ſauing little geſting woulde diſproue doctrine thereby ſay iohn baptiſt calleth math 3 phariſies heades church doctoures generation viper would therefore conclude doctrine naught thinke ſo chyldiſh ſéemeth one ſentence rayling ſlaundering haue written wil ſay chriſt called ſcribes phariſies hypocrite math 15 16 22 13 ſéemeth rayle aboue meaſure calleth thē hypocrite reprouing papiſticall hypocrite muſt called rayling blinde guide paynted ſepulchers whych outwardlye appeare righteous within full hypocriſie ſerpents generation ʋipers beſides calleth herode foxe luc 13 iewes luc 13 called froward aduouterous generation math 12 16 17 ſayth vnfaythfull ouerthwart nation woulde thinke ſhould excuſe iewes refuſed doctrine ſay rayled reaſonable man woulde thinke thoſe thing pointes belonging vertue rather ſpices braunches pride hée ſhewed hym ſelfe charitable malicious wiſedome therein folie would excuſe ſay bene one halfe yeare ſchole diſcretion charitie ſhould haue proſpered vertuous learning bene ſcholes ſclanderyng rayling ieſtyng finally paule eye might appeare rayle ſlaunder cleane deſtitute god ſpirite luke ſaith repleniſhed luc 13 holy ghoſt ſayd clemas reſiſteth hym actes 13 thou ful ſuttelty deceite thou ſonne deuill enemy righteouſnes ceaſeth peruerte rightwayes lord bryng many •• ſuch ſayinges peter iohn iames iudas yet thincke improue doctrine thereby becauſe ſtudye ſhorte ſhall count ſufficient haue warned reader notwithſtanding peraduenture raſtell wil yet aunſwered ſay albeit haue touched inough concernyng thoſe thynges appeare railyng ſlanderyng eye yet brought none ieſt whereunto may aunſwere alledge helias prophetes apoſtles great reprouers vngodly wicked prophet mocked falſe prieſtes ieſted ſaying call loude vnto god peraduenture ſléepe cā el gone towne cannot inough meruell brother raſtell would vſe ſuch maner reaſoning improue doctrine becauſe raylyng ieſtyng ther hath made foule hole kinſmans beſt coate euery mā perceiueth bookes ſo full rayling geſtyng baudye tale furious momus venus take theyr partes ſhould little left vulcanus raſtellafter raſtell diſſenteth purpoſe matter would proue expoſitions scripture good becauſe occaſion bryng yt people boldnes ſinne moue people delite men faultes laugh therat put exāple ſayth ſhould take vpon expoſitiō text principio erat verbum verbum erat apud deum c expound maner fond expoſition ſo falſe metrein begynnyng yeare iohn frith noble clerke killed mylſtone ſpere keepe well geeſe dogges barke trowe ſayth raſtell wiſe men would thinke fonde expoſition yet expoſition would pleaſe childrē fooles mad men well expoſition auſten hierome doctor ye church becauſe would make laugh ſo ſayth raſtell frith maketh ſuch expoſitiōs ieſtyng rayling make people laugh regardyng edifie people prouoke vertue mekenes charitie leaue ſinne rather geueth boldnes beleue purgatory ſore fond ſaying raſtell hell mocketh ieſteth thoſe reaſons bee made proofe purgatory touchyng firſt part firth ſaith expoſitions occaſion bryng people boldnes ſinne aſke hym aunſwere becauſe geue thē boldnes purgatory yet hell thereto raſtell leaue maketh fitten dare ſay hee frith good ſcholer ſone hath lerned leſſon ſay lye bitter maketh lye hee would call rayling neuer denyed hell affirme many place booke euē firſt ſide myne aunſwere agaynſt affirme hell perpetuall damnation ye come proofe wordes ſhall ſée wiſely mā cōcludeth thinketh ab inferiori ad ſuū ſuperius confuſe diſtribue men ſhall thinke good conſequent ſhould ſay lacke fire priſō would cōclude lacked fire middleſex wold ſay wit raſtels head would hee conclude witte mās head hath ſo long ſtudyed philoſophy hee hath cleane forgotten principal sophiſtry notwithſtandyng wil forgeue faute man ſomewhat aged therfore thinke lōg ſince read memory neuertheleſſe ſay hys argument ſoluted although denye hell yet denye purgatory ſo geue people occaſiō ſinne becauſe feare purgatory whereunto haue ſo ſufficiently aunſwered raſtels vij argument wonder hee ſhamed bryng ſame agayne truſteth bookes ſhall neuer read may go ſurely abroad therefore may ſay onely hee careth ſaith ſo hold peace hee reporteth raſtell make expoſitions make people delite heare mēs fautes laugh thereat therto ſay nay till layſure proue frith ſayth ſhould take vppon hym expounde principio erat verbum maner raſtellin begynnyng yeare iohn frith noble clerke killed mylſtone ſpere keepe well geeſe dogges barke saying wiſe men would ſay fonde expoſition therto aunſwere ſaying frith ryme meter might well ſay gooſe made gooſe would haue made better ryme meter raſtell reaſon therin yet touchyng meter ſecond verſe lacketh foote ſhorter felowes put word frith put worde raſtell ſhall meter alſo perfite halting verſe ſhal runne merely felowes vppon hys right féete maner begynnyng yeare iohn raſtell noble clerke killed mylſtone ſpere keepe well geeſe dogges barke thus haue amended meter frith taketh payne amende raſtels meter reaſon reaſon leaue ſelfe amende layſure end ſecond chapter ſayth entende expoſitions bring people beleue foure great errours wherof firſt hell ordeined chriſtes faith although neuer ſo many ſinnes let v ſée proueth aunſwer wythout ſpot wrincle ſuch thing ſhould holy wythoute blame vpon theſe textes conclude frith chriſte haue ſo purged v wtout ſpot wrinckle blame ſight paule teſtifieth wil neuer caſt v purgatorie ſhould purged withoute ſpotte wrinckle blame ſomwhat declare matter ſinners lōg liue yet without ſynne ſight god adde theſe woordes would men well note bicauſe raſtell leaueth beſt matter rehearſe owne good woorkes neuer knew chriſtian man deny elſe touching matter nothing purpoſe well mighte haue improued bicauſe bring text proue yt father heauen god proue neuer man doubted alleageth paul ro v vj raſtell ſaying though grace doe raigne thorow chriſt ſhall therfore dwel ſinne nay god forbid ſayth paule euen ſo ſay againe alleageth rom viij dampnation raſtell ſetteth trap wherein wilbe taken hym ſelfe chriſt ieſu liue fleſhe euen ſo ſay raſtell ſay contrary anone beſides alleageth rom iij fréely iuſtified grace chriſtes redemption ſhew hys iuſtice remiſſyon ſynne done yet ſaythe raſtell paule ſayth law deſtroyed fayth made ſtable thys hathe frith left boke cauſe people beléeue cleane purged bloud chriſte néede purgatorie theſe word may euidently frith perceyue raſtell meaneth thys alleaging paule eſtabliſhing lawe verely worke lawe ſhould iuſtifie workes law iuſtifie v cleane purge ſynne whyche contrary paul ſcrypture euen thys ſame chapter alleageth paule ſaith workes law fleſh ſhalbe iuſtified hys ſyght ſaythe rightwiſeneſſe god commeth faythe ieſu chriſt vnto vppon beléeue touching good work wil touch héereafter furthermore raſtell ſayth raſtell argumentes coulde proue purgatory muſt follow raſtelles blind argument wel hell v chriſten men though continue ſtill ſinne bleſſed ſpot wrinkle blame therefore caſt v purgatory caſt v hell whatſoeuer ſinne commit raſtell vttereth blindenes frith vnto ſheweth vnderſtanding hath ſcripture firſt armeth himſelfe wyth falſe ſuppoſition yet therupon concludeth argument falſly ſuppoſition al men baptized materiall water chriſten men haue true fayth note well worthy learned argument thoſe paule affirmeth without ſpot blame wrinkle thereto ſay nay euen outwarde circumciſion made iewes elect people child ſaluation
